Compared to this bomb I think about changing my votes to some other stinkers one or two notches up. This movie is bad from start to finish. The only decent scenes are the FX-sequences during the final battle. Everything else was simply unwatchable. What's most surprising on anyone involved with this dub is that they still have ongoing and/or rising careers after this one. "Director" Roger Christian has made something called "The outlaws and the starship Redwing" (IMDB-entry as: Starship) which I actually saw in a theatre in 1985 and guess what: It`s nearly as bad as BE. So Mr. Christian may be one of the worst directors working today but he is at least dependable. And he must have something going for him because he is making a new movie this time in Mexico... Barry Pepper did *61 Knockaround guys and We were soldiers afterwards Forest Whitaker is directing something new and John Travolta is still going on to cash in one big paycheck after another. And most amazing is the fact that there still are rumors about Travolta's wish to do a sequel. So whats left is one of the worst movies ever.

To take the positive side first the creation of the state of the world in the movie was realistically made.But wheres the plot I could not find the thin red line through the movie the directing and acting stinks. Switching between scenes are terrible created.The one thing that saves this movie from the note 1 is the creation of the scenarios.

As a legitimate movie? This movie is a solid 1/10. As an awful movie to watch with drunk friends and laugh about its awfulness? 10/10 would watch again.I think underneath Travolta's awful acting the unrealistic lack of blood the amateur scene transitions and the absolute lack of logic any of the script seems to have there lies a movie that could be somewhat average. I think I would've felt more inclined to take it seriously if the scene transitions alone would've been better but alas!On serious notes one of the biggest things holding this movie back was that characters constantly felt the need to tell you what was going on instead of letting you come to that conclusion on your own. It's annoying when characters in movies unnecessarily narrate their actions and explain their motives because people don't just do that in real life. There's more subtlety. Additionally all of the action sequences are quick-cut nonsensical messes. You must be a genius if you can keep track of what the characters are even doing in any of the action scenes because I could not for the life of me keep up with them.To sum it up this movie truly is an experience; not to be seen but to be felt in the depths of your soul. A quick insight into the beauty of this movie: I'm pretty sure the word "leverage" is said more than 50 times.

What gripped me? It certainly wasn't the plot/acting/camera-work. Perhaps it was John Travoltas faux-English accent? his swaying nostril strings? or perhaps the funky dreadlocks perched atop a glowing spam head? No it has to be his swinging whale of a cod-piece. Mercifully the camera happens to avoid his nether-region in most shots but beware there is a monster lurking down there. Meanwhile a 'movie' takes place around this cumbersome object. The plot was clearly written by said Cod-Piece for there is no other excuse for this dribbling mess. Regardless Battlefield: Earth is well worth a watch if only to work out how the actors in this homage to L. Ron Hubbard delusional space opera ever managed to salvage a career in the aftermath. The cod-piece out-acted the whole sorry lot of them.

This is the WORST movie I have ever seen. I thought by the trailers that this movie was going to be reasonable good however upon actually watching the movie I am convinced that it would be a miracle if somebody could make a movie worse than this. Unless you have had a lobotomy DO NOT WATCH this movie. I have wasted my money at the theaters watching it I urge you not to do the same by renting or buying it. Scientology ought to be ashamed of itself after all this is the story of Scientology's view of what will happen to the world.

The only reason this movie got a single star is because I couldn't rate it any lower. The plot matches about 3% of what the book takes you through. The book would score a solid 8.5-9 whereas this movie after reading the book makes me want to personally ask the writers director and basically all of the cast and crew what they were thinking. This is one movie I will NEVER watch again. So many things missing! The only redemption would be a limited series that actually followed the book. Please spare yourself you've been warned!

column4: Not Even Entertainingly Bad Just Boring
column5: Blame MST3K but I'm highly entertained by epically bad movies such as The Room and Caligula.Viewing many of the youtube reviews of this title I thought it would make that list. But I simply found it boring and uninteresting. The acting was generally bad especially the lines by the love interest.The special effects were dated even for the time when CGI was not as well integrated with practical effects as it is now.The sets looked like the same old abandoned warehouses of post apocalyptic movies with a lesser budget making much of it very unconvincing.The story and setting seemed like it was trying to be a 90's epic but didn't quite make it to the next ledge of that canyon and fell into nothingness.Whereas the Room keeps you on the edge of your seat excited for what badness lays right around the next corner this moving was like a boring drone of badness.Couldn't even finish.Guess I won't be converting to scientology any time soon.

It was the middle of summer around 8:00 at night and I had nothing else to do. I flipped through the channels and came upon Battlefield Earth. It seemed mildly interesting so I watched it.WORST MISTAKE EVER.First I was so confused to the point I didn't even learn the characters names. I had to go on Wikipedia afterwards to figure that out. The acting was atrocious and I sat through every single episode of Cavemen. I'm a bit of a Trekkie I admit it and I swear the makeup makes them all look like Klingons from that one Enterprise episode where there was a disease etc! I half expected Michael Dorn to walk out! Now I think maybe three years after watching it its awfulness still haunts me. This is the worst movie I have ever seen and I waste of my time.DON'T EVEN WATCH IT TO MAKE FUN OF IT'S HORRENDOUSNESS. YOU WILL NOT SURVIVE.

column4: It's awful but not the worst
column5: Battlefield Earth has been called the worst film of the 2000's and even of all time. The dialogue is terrible the acting is terrible the characters are beyond stupid but I have experienced worse. It isn't even close to worst film of all time but it is still a failure. Years from now it will be a cult classic. This is a perfect film for people to do video reviews on. There is so many things done wrong in the film that many people will have different things to complain about. It is one of those films that fails in everything except in actually failing. If you don't want to make a bad movie don't do what these people do. Not the worst but a complete failure that everyone can agree on.1/2 of a star out of 4

I saw the movie Battlefield Earth and enjoyed it tremendously. I read the book twice and could not put it down each time it had my interest all night long. The movie was pretty faithful to the book and Pepper was ideal as the hero. As I read the book I visualized what I was reading. I wondered what the movie would be like and to tell the truth the movie was different but then I am not the director and I looked at the movie through his eyes and I liked that. The Psychlos were bad the heroes were good and the action had my attention throughout. Hours after the movie is over I am still thinking about it and to me that is a good sign. dougers-2

I've seen much worse. It would have been an OK TV movie. I've read the book but it's been so many years the movie's departures didn't phase me. The effects were as stunning as we've grown to expect from sci-fi lately. Travolta was as gleefully evil as the novel had his character. Everything was up to par as far as the movie was concerned.But maybe that's the problem.We've seen evil before so no big deal. We've seen fighters vs. alien ships before no big deal. We've seen the planet devastated and the cities in ruin before. Same old same old.The movie's flaws were the same as the book: One thousand years would cause more damage to the earth than was shown. Rubber degrades in just a few years fuel evaporates batteries would no longer even be able to hold a charge. Even nuclear warheads have a shelf life much less than a millennium.Also there's a problem of language. When isolated language changes. Right here in America we have several different dialects after a few hundred years and we're in constant contact with each other. After a thousand years no one would still speak english well enough to read the Declaration of Independence yet Johnny can talk to every human he meets.I'll never understand how anyone can see a 1050 page novel and believe they can tell the story in a movie. They would have been better to have made a TV mini-series. But the movie as a movie wait for it to come out on video.

column4: I want that two hours of my life back!
column5: Okay everyone has seen review after review pointing out the utter idiocy that is Battlefield Earth. I must reiterate however to drive home the point: DO NOT SEE THIS MOVIE. Or if you must buy a ticket for an actually worthy movie and theater hop don't reward the people who put out this wretched abomination with your money. I was a fortunate one one of my friends paid for the ticket not me. And if he thinks he's ever getting his money from me he's got another thing coming. However I will never get back the precious wasted hours of my life. Save yourselves! At many points I must wonder whether the script was in fact the fault of Hubbard or a five-year old child. One or the other thought that it would be really cool to have a bunch of stone-using tribesmen zoom around in Harriers. But wait not only are the tribesmen able to restore thousand-year-old fighters fuel and arm them in a magical military base that still has power after those thousand years they can also talk to each other without any headsets or other radio equipment while flying around! Psychic tribesmen! Who after that thousand years know phrases like "Piece of cake" and "I'm on his tail".But even if the screenplay was written by this hypothetical child Hubbard is still responsible for the "hero" Johnny Goodboy. Who the hell names a character Johnny Goodboy? And why does he have no personality at all? I mean none! He strives to emulate Braveheart with little failed attempts at rousing speeches but they come across as flat and pathetic as the rest of the acting. The Psyclos aren't nearly as intimidating as they should be just how much can the audience fear an ultimate enemy that you could defeat with an egg in a jar with an opening too small to fit their fist through? On top of that they still manage to trust the Terl guy despite the fact that he goes out of his way to screw over everyone he passes by. You could easily cause a Psyclo to have a seizure just by asking "No means yes and yes means no do you want me to hit you?"In any event if you think that a galvanic skin tester can cure your spiritual ills and that giving $400000 to become an Operant Theta VIII is a good idea then run to see this movie! If you are not yet in the clutches of Hubbard's happy family then avoid it at all costs. I'm convinced it's a Scientology plot to numb the brains of the viewers so much that their warped technobabble makes sense in comparison.

I've read many comments and reviews of this movie but I went anyway. I read the book over 15 years ago and loved it. On the cover of the book was "Soon to be a Major Motion Picture" I've been waiting since then and I am definitely disappointed. After reading the book a trilogy or mini-series would be needed to tell the whole story so I had my doubts when I heard a movie was finally coming out.The one thing that I disliked the most about this movie was John Travolta's acting. I like John Travolta he's had some great roles but he tries to pull off the "Jack Nicholson's Joker" the bad guy that steals the show. Why does he slip into a British/Scottish accent? column4: The movie was good the book was better
column5: To summarize: It is the year 3000. Earth has been conquered by the Psychlos a race of arrogant miners. Mankind has been reduced to a few remaining barbaric tribes who are nearing extinction. What ensues is mankind's last fight to free Earth from tyranny.I read the book about four years ago and it was one of the best stories I have ever read. Now I realize that any movie adapted from a novel is not going to be able to incorporate EVERYTHING from the book it comes from I still missed some things that were in the book. However that doesn't mean the movie story is bad.Acting was a mixed bag somewhat. Though I felt the problem was a little more the screenplay than the actors themselves. Travolta is good as Terl the Psychlo security chief(though I could have done without the accent which seemed to come and go). Some might see him as incredibly stupid to overlook some thing which goes on with humans. You have to realize something Psychlos and Terl in particular are so arrogant in thier alleged superiority to humans they don't consider humans to be intelligent let alone sentient. Whitaker I thought did a commendable job as Ker. The part is written differently than in the book where Ker is a midget Psychlo outcast but Forrest makes Ker work in his role as Terl's lackey. Pepper has his moments as Jonnie though I couldn't quite entirely get behind him as the hero. again though I think it's more the screenplay than the actor's ability. Kim Coates was interesting as Carlo. I'm dissapointed that they turn one of the more interesting characters in the novel Robert the Fox into a painted spear throwing tribal leader.Special effects were excellent though I thought some of the battle scenes were a bit too dark to really see the action.Directing was............well lets just say Roger Christian does an excellent job of being George Lucas Jr. Though I guess I can't really blame the guy you could pick worse directors to emulate.The story was basically good and keeps the main points of the book and is entertaining. but it doesn't quite allow you to suspend belief enough to go along readily with the notion that Harrier jets have managed to survive 1000 years intact. But heythis wouldn't be the first movie in the world with plot holes.To sum it up this was a good movie. Not great but good. It's one you should check out at least once.

Nothing and I mean NOTHING previously produced could possibly prepare you for this incredible waste of money time and talent.If you want to watch sub-par moviemaking rent some films directed by Ed Wood Jr.; you'll enjoy them more than this pile of rubbish.

column4: This was a true 30's style adventure
column5: Though the book was indeed "different" I believe that Travolta and company have completely captured the intent of the author that Terl be unfeeling and VERY funny. The movie based of the 1982 C.Ron Hobbard Scientology novel "Battlefield Earth" has to do with the aftermath of an alien invasion of the earth in which almost the entire human race was wiped out. Those humans still alive some 1000 years after D-Day when the invading Psychols defeated all the armies on earth back in the year 2000 are living in more or less cave man times being hunted down by the evil Psychols to do manual labor in their coal and gold mines.Jonnie Barry Pepper living in the caves with his fellow surviving humans in the Colorado Rockies decides to take off for civilization in the nearby destroyed city of Denver with him not knowing what's in store for him and his fellow humans that he later hooks up with. Running into a group of Psychols Jonnie & friends are quickly captured and inducted into the human or man-animal work gangs. The human work gangs do mining for gold in around the Boulder Colorado area by the Psychols who's head of security on earth is Terl John Travolta is in charge of.Terl who's being eaten up by the fact that he has to stay on earth forever by his boss back on his home planet of Psychol which makes him even meaner and more despicable then he already was. Were later given to understand that the sleazy Terl had a secret tryst with the boss' daughter that lead to him being banished to live out his last years on earth the worst according to Terl planet in the Milky Way Galaxy.Finding out from a satellite photo that there's a secret and large mother-load or vein of gold in the Rockies Terl plans together with his not too bright Psychol sidekick KarForrest Whitaker to get the gold mined and dug out by the captured human or man-animals and keep it for themselves without the Psychols big shots knowing a thing about it. Training Jonnie with this Psychol learning machine to mine the gold Terl doesn't realize that he's also teaching the illiterate human the history of freedom and democracy and the men and women who fought and died to attain it over the centuries. Jonnie is also thought how to fly USAF F-15's and F-16's combat planes and even detonate nuclear devices that in the end will do in both Terl and his fellow Psychols on earth as well as those on his home planet of Psychol.Outragous looking aliens with what looks like clothespins attached to their noses as breathing aids as they completely come apart from the determined attacks of the fearless and newly revived humans who almost overnight come alive with a fleet of fighter planes that they got from the deserted US military base in Texas Ft Hood. The revolting humans also grab weapons from the fleeing Psychols as they not only defeat the hated and brutal aliens but by teleporting a super nuclear device knock out and totally destroy the aliens planet of Psychol as well.Both John Travolta and Forrest Whitaker look and act totally ridicules fighting and screwing with each other like Cramdon & Norton in the TV comedy show the Honeymooners over who'll end up as the big banana with the pot of gold at the end of the rainbow. Travolta talks in such a strange and uncommon for him weird tone that I think that his voice was dubbed in by someone else. Whitaker is so blown up that he looks like he added or filled himself up with over 100 pounds for his role in the movie as as Ker.The battle scenes between the humans and Psychols are completely unbelievable with the humans lead by ace fighter pilot Robert the Fox Richard Tyson who just hours before didn't even know what a plane looked like much less being able to fly it. The Fox knocks out dozens of Psychol aircraft that are light years ahead in combat ability then his fleet of outdated flying jalopies that are over 1000 old years old. Fox does all this without his fighter planes having being maintained during all that time and yet somehow has their tanks filled up with jet fuel that hasn't been pumped out of the ground and refined for over ten centuries!The movie "Battlefield Earth" is only good for a few laughs and that's about all with nothing really making any sense and even the special effects that were about the only things that could have possibly saved it coming across as phony and primitive as if they were from a sci-fi flick made in the 1950's.

column4: 'Robot Monster' for the new millennium: entertainingly awful
column5: After a thousand years of suppression a few remaining humans rebel against the Psychlos evil entrepreneurs from outer-space. There is not much more I can add to the decades of derision that has been deservedly heaped on this canonical example of how not to make a big-budget science-fiction extravaganza. The plot is nonsensical the script laughable the cinematography vertiginous and the acting borderline amateur at times. Star and Hollywood-powerhouse behind the film's creation John Travolta channels a rogue Vinnie Barbarino as the greedy hydrocephalic space-bully Terl and his snide 'jocularly menacing' delivery is so clichd as to be almost self-satirising. Forest Whittaker mugs it up as Terl's put upon deputy Ker and Berry Pepper is the paper-thin rebel leader Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (aka "Ratbrian"). The ludicrousness of the film's vision is apparent from the earliest frames which see the ragged human survivors living like primordial savages in primitive villages all with perfect teeth and most of whom look like they just stepped out of the make-up chair at a fashion show. Everything goes downhill from there until the show-stopping stupidity of the discovery of the seemingly everlasting cache of arms and jet fighters at what was Fort Hood (after a detour to Fort Knox at which the last person to leave had forgotten to shut the vault). From this abyss the film has nowhere to go but up and the final battle and comeuppance to the miserably snide Psyclos is preposterous but fun to watch. Needless to say given the source material (a novel by Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard) the film's back-story is as interesting as the film itself. 'Battlefield Earth' is marginally more watchable than 1953's legendarily dumb 'Robot Monster' but at a cost: Travolta's salary was 625 times 'Robot Monster's' entire budget (100 times if corrected for inflation). Sometimes you don't get what you pay for but a least the more recent film's critical assassination didn't drive the director to attempt suicide.

column4: Its so bad it made me laugh at points...
column5: After seeing the Nostalgia Critic's 100th episode in which he reviewed BattleField Earth I didn't know what to think and after a few months curiosity got the better of me and I went in search of this film on the internet while I was home sick. And BOY oh BOY does this film suck. Everything about it sucks the characters (who don't develop) the effects are crap the story is confusing at points the movie itself drags the acting is a joke and I kept finding myself pointing out stupid points as well as plot holes.I won't really talk about the story much but in a nutshell earth has been ruled by an incredibly stupid race called Psychlos for one thousand years and the humans (or Man animals as the psychlos call them) are in constant hiding from the psychlos and are on the verge of extinction and the hero johnny tries to come up with a plan to take back earth. One of the psychlos called Terl is forced to stay on earth as chief of security for reasons unknown and he wants to buy his way off earth by training the "man animals" to mine gold because apparently gold is the rarest of all minerals.While the plot sounds simple its hard to follow and full of plot holes.The psychlos are perhaps the DUMMBEST alien race known to man they let the humans roam free to the point where they actually kill a couple of psychlos Terl lets a machine teach Johnny all about the psychlos all the psychlos underestimate the humans and apparently the psychlos have so many health problems I keep asking myself how in the mother of God did these morons conquer ANY planet? Travolta (who plays Terl) I believe didn't try in the slightest to act in this movie and he's the dumbass who's responsible for this movie! However his role actually made me laugh at points as well as a lot of the psychlos stupidity did. But the crappy trophy award for worst actor and character goes to Johnny (Pepper). This guy is easily the worst frigging actor I have ever seen! his character is unrealistic and psychotic and just unlikeable.Now The reason why I give this movie a star more than twilight or son of the mask is because this movie made me laugh and some of the action was some what enjoyable but then again saying this movie is better than twilight or son of the mask is like saying it doesn't hurt being stabbed my this knife as much as it does with THIS knife. Bottom line I WOULD say don't watch this movie but I think in order to believe me you have to see it to believe it.

Besides the evil Scientologists um I mean Psyklos being absurdly laughable (dreadlocks and moon boots) the entire film just didn't take itself seriously.There is so much potential in the story but nothing was followed through resulting in shallow if any plot hollow characters who were merely caricatures inept special effects and inane attempts at credibility.Every copy of this film should be returned to the studio where it should be burned and the ashes swept up and buried in a deep abandoned salt mine.

column4: This film has no scope. It can really only be enjoyed by hardcore science fiction fans.
column5: The previews made this movie look so good! I guess most previews do but Battlefield Earth was particularly disappointing. Most of the special effects and camera-work were fairly effective and the character make-up was also very well-done except for the tired concept of colored contact lenses. Those were getting old 1000 years before the film took place! You'd think a superior race such as the Psychlos would be able to come up with something a little more creative than that.Although the acting was all very good it was a mistake to put John Travolta in this film. This is a complaint that I have about numerous films like this John Travolta is just too well known to suddenly play such an intensely evil character as he did in this film.One of the main problems with this film comes mainly from discrepancies in the believability of the plot. (possible spoiler ahead!!) The one that jumps immediately to mind is the fact that the 'man-animals' managed to conquer a superior race like the Psychlos using primitive Harrier jets which they learned to fly in a matter of days using a flight simulator which along with the jets they found to be in perfect working order after sitting for 1000 years!!The downfall of Battelfield Earth stems from this blatant disrespect for reality. True this is characteristic of science fiction but L. Ron Hubbard must realize that our current military is unable to build jets that could be left sitting until the year 3000 and still be made to work. You'd think at least the TIRES would have rotted away if nothing else. Battlefield Earth is entertaining but also ultimately disappointing.

I sometimes like bad films (The Avengers) I sometimes hate good films (Magnolia) but in this case I hated a bad film. The film is inexcusable because any film with a good cast and large budget should at least be OK with both of these factors wasted and coupled with a appalling story and techinque and you have in short the worst film ever.

Then I went and read the book (yep all 1100+ pages) and quite frankly I don't know how this colossus of sci-fi rambling got published.In the year 3000 humanity is on the brink of extinction by a race Bob Marley Klingons called Psychlos who have come to Earth to economically exploit it. Our hero Johnny Goodboy (Barry Pepper) leads a rebellion with still-operating Harriers and nuclear bombs. Go figure.John Travolta (Terl the lead Psychlo) should be ashamed of himself for bringing this to the screen. And we should all be ashamed for watching it. Avoid like radiation-saturated breathe gas.1/10

Maybe the huge Budget on this movie went up the Director's nose

column4: This movie is unfairly rated...considering all Steven Segal movies rate higher
column5: I saw this movie with no hope of seeing a decent flick considering all the tragic reviews I'd heard. I was very pleasantly surprised to find this movie is actually very entertaining as far as Hollywood action movies go. Good characters good story and a fair dose of action. As per all Hollywood movies you just need to get your head around the unbelievable events that make the story work usually things like people being in the right places at the right times and 1 in a billion coincidences etc that always seem to take place on the silver screen in this movies case the adult primitive humans all seem to have a learning curve equal to Einstein to the power of 10. Lets face it this movie is not reality but very very few action/sci-fi movies are if any. If you take into account that every single one of Steven Segals pathetic predictable nothing new movies in this database rates higher than Battlefield Earth you must surely agree that this movie has been very unfairly rated.

A cult classic before its time. Now match Battlefield Earth with the latest Disney corporate/Toys"R"Us sponsored regurgitated Star Wars 7-8-9-10-11 hairball and this sci-fi campy movie comes across as Gone with the Wind of space.Whatever it's not its not forgettable just sit back and enjoy the details & interesting back story . Travolta gives his smarmy best playing against Forest Whitaker as the dolt sidekick trying desperately to get off the boring apocalyptic planet Earth.First they must make enough profit to bribe the Psychlos home bureaucrats to issue a ticket home as a reward for enriching the oligarchy . Alien NWO capitalist mining Gold with human slave labor & despoiling the environment all at the same time. Picture the Psychlos as British Petroleum mining for oil in the Gulf of Mexico...that's a stretch but I understand where L. Ron Hubbard was coming from.Now the two are trying to do this without being issued a mining permit from the Psychlos home world and shipping the wealth home on the sly. To do this the two miscreants must use the human slaves as pawns(Iraq Wars) as mindless draft animals to pull of thus heist (Oil) but unbeknownst the human slaves will rebel with the help of hero Johnny Goodboy...campy but still interesting in the grand story that reflects are New World Order of today. Not many movies will tackle geopolitical scams & schemes of today wrapped around a campy Alien invasion Sci-fi story line they usually go hardcore preachiness that defeats the messageOnly reason not to give this a Ten is the human hero is miscast needed a stronger personality as Travolta & Whitaker carry the show . This movie should have been made in the 1980's by John Carpenter and it would have gone down as a classic. I think much of the hate is directed at Travolta  Scientology & parroted by the internet herd mentality and not the story. Everyone says it's bad so it must be so. Star Wars # must be great because everyone says so no critic wants to say the whole franchise is garbage now because social/ media wont allow the honest truth without seeing the back-end of the unemployment line. Just as everyone has the cowardly Lion courage to troll Battlefield Earth ...it's an easy mark. A taste of junkfood Star Wars cinema leftovers is enough but you just might catch yourself watching B.E for the second or third time on antenna or Netflix for a late night snack.This is Mystery Science Theater 3000 material but in an odd way a enjoyable romp across time & space. A cross between Space Balls & Blade Runner .

column4: THE WORST MOVIE OF ALL TIME!!!!!!!!!!!!
column5: How does a movie like this even get made. The shots are all slanted at 45 degrees. the production design looks like crap and the CGI is GOD AWFUL! John Travolta is WAY over the top in this movie. These aliens are supposed to be so advanced and smarter than us but they are all dumb ass'. One of the dumb scenes is the food scene. John Travolta wonders what food that human like the most. They assume that they like rats but the humans chose rats because they were starving. Honestly I could write so much for this but I want to keep it small. I do have to talk about the end where the aliens planet is blown up by one small bomb. Yeah the writing and story is that bad! Please stay away from this movie.

Directed by Roger Christian. Starring Barry Pepper John Travolta Forest Whitaker Kim Coates Sabine Karsenti Richard Tyson Michael MacRae Kelly Preston. (PG-13)Bottom-of-the-barrel science fiction adventure catastrophe based on the first half of L. Ron Hubbard's massive novel is one of the more infamous failures in film history. Even the least discerning genre fans in the world could smell the stink coming off this one (and not just because everything looks so grungy and foul). Story about mankind fighting back against their enslaving alien overlords isn't an especially interesting one; required to sell it are well-utilized tropes punchy dialogue and characterizations visually exciting design and effects and flashes of wit and excitement. Unfortunately this film has none of those things (unless shooting about eighty-five percent of the movie at a Dutch angle is considered "visually exciting design") with astounding lapses in logic and laughable performances to boot--either shapelessly generic (Pepper) or incalculably weird and over-the-top (Travolta). One of the worst-looking would-be blockbusters ever released and not even that amusing to watch for purposes of ridicule because of how boring the whole thing is. Self-respecting man-animals should stay far far away.5/100

column4: I really Liked this Film. (This review contains Spoilers)
column5: Battlefield Earth is a film that cannot be taken seriously. This film is one of my personal favorites. I have fun whenever I watch the DVD. Well the plot to this story is easy to follow. The film takes place 1000 years into the future and we have been conquered by a race known as the Phyclos. The Phyclos reminded me of overgrown Ferengi from the Star Trek Spinoffs. They are only concerned with wealth and Power. John Travolta does an excellent job as Teryl the Psyclo Chief of security who hates being on Earth and desperately wants a transfer. Well his superiors decide to leave him them permanently. He then launches a plot to buy off his superiors by using humans (the lower species) to mine gold in a high radiation zone which interferes with the Psyclos breathing gas. Well he gives an earthling Psyclo knowledge so that he can operate complex Psyclo machinery which will have dire consequences in the end for the Psyclos. Well This earthling named "Johnny" (portrayed by Barry Pepper) outsmarts the Psyclos by giving them gold from Fort Know (which still exits). It was hilarious when Teryl finds the gold and wonders how these earthlings can smelt the gold into bricks. During the time they are supposed to mine the gold they plan an attack from abandoned U.S bunkers. Well enough with the plot. I want to talk about how great this movie is. First of all I loved the camera angles there isnt one straight shot in the whole film. I also loved the effects and lighting. Lastly I thought this film was highly amusing. Watch Teryl and his assistant trying to get leverage over each other was quite amusing. I mean it was directed by Roger Christian and designed by Patrick Tatopoulos who both worked on "Independence Day" and "Star Wars" Battlefield Earth shouldn't be taken seriously though it isnt my favorite Sci-Fi film I enjoyed this one very much and I know I am in the minority. I cant wait for the sequel.

I knew going into Battlefield Earth movie that it was going to be bad. I had read reviews comparing it to the worst of Ed Wood's science fiction. Reading this I expected at least enough cheesy fun to sustain interest for roughly two hours. What I found instead was a nauseating sleep inducing monument in the history of bad cinema. I can't help but feel pity for the poor ignorant fools who actually seemed to think they had a good movie on their hands. I have a hard time believing John Travolta will be able to regain a reputation after starring in a movie in which the logic behind characters' actions is even less balanced than the camera which is at a tilt on every shot. Mr. Travolta's character plans to find out what humans like to eat best by starving them to a point of desperation and seeing what they eat. Simply presenting this logic as something that anyone especially someone who proves himself clever throughout the rest of the movie would use is completely ridiculous. In their plan to save the world the humans plan to collapse a dome made with glass and metal beams that covers the city thereby letting in gas that is poisonous only to the Psychlos. What doesn't seem to pose any problems is the fact that huge steal beams will falls from the sky. But hey it's the future. Steal beams fall only on bad guys and bad guys always belt out an evil cackle

As a published Science Fiction author I went to this movie with some trepidation. I loved the book but could anybody turn it into a decent flick? You bet! This was a terrific film and I enjoyed it tremendously. All of the characters had backgrounds and the aliens were here for an actual purpose rather than the childish Star Wars nonsense of 'we're just doing this because we're evil. Ha-ha so there.' The Special Effects were first rate and the scriptwriter did a bang-up job of converting Hubbard's huge (1100 page) novel to the silver screen. With plenty of material in the novel left over for a sequel or even two. Kudos to the cast and crew. Well done!

column4: Please read book before watching genre movie
column5: A classic sci-fi book made into film the story is so multi-layered and long(around 1500 pages) it's impossible to have it make sense in an almost 2 hour film. If you enjoyed the book it would definitely make way more sense. I gave it 8 stars as I really enjoyed it it stayed true to the books storyline and included enough of the background to please fans of the book. I was actually surprised at how well done it was despite all the negative reviews. A similar case would be "Dune"  I tried watching it without having read Frank Herberts classic book and was quickly lost. Read the book and it and the film became among my all time favorites.

I didn't think it was quite as bad as everyone who's bashing the film was making out. However I definitely do not think that the film is as good as the Scientology cult shills are making out either. If anything I would describe this film as being hopeless in its mediocrity. It also makes me wonder how a man who wrote something this stupid could possibly have formed a new deathcult... oh wait the Christian bible is even worse.Anyway the plusses of the film are extremely simple. I went to this film wanting to be entertained and apart from a few moments where the film drags I was entertained. The leading lady was wonderful to look at. I'd repopulate the planet with her any time she asked me to that's for certain. The special effects were nowhere near as bad as I was led to believe they were either. Sure they were patently unconvincing but I didn't mind that at all.The bad points of this film? Well the acting is attrocious even from Travolta which leads me to believe that the real problem was with the script rather than the actors. Instead of trying to verbatim copy a portion of the novel it would have been more prudent to make an independent story of its own and should that prove more successful get a more talented writer to translate the actual novel to the screen. Then there's the Psychlos who seemed to be about as menacing as a schoolteacher and about as frightening as a child abuser. No offence meant to other people who've been victims of either but once you take away their weapons and technology these guys would really have been as weak as a Catholic inquisitor without an army.Another low point of the film is that we are never given enough opportunity to form an attachment with any of the characters. Their dialogue is recited in a very contrite and false manner that prevents any connection making it very hard to want to root for the cavemen. Firing at the week-long training in jump-jet flying is a bit weak... obviously they had to make some kind of shortcut like that in order to get the story moving ahead. Shooting at Terl's constant superiority pose is another weak move on the part of critics as this is exactly what weak little bullies do in order to reassure themselves of their position. Trust me I should know having recently confronted one of the teachers of my boyhood and suddenly finding that I outweighed them by ninety pounds (not because I am fat either). It's just a self-assuring pose guys it's actually a nice touch.All in all I give this film two out of ten. It's entertaining both in spite of and because of its stupidity and that's more than what I can say for such films as the Blair Witch Nazi Propaganda which still makes me want to perpetrate violence upon the directors because I value my own freedom to think. Give it a shot expecting a patently stupid movie and it might keep you laughing for a while.

column4: This movie doesn't deserve that low rating
column5: Yes the story was kind of thin but a movie doesn't deserve that low rating because of that. The special effects are great and the acting was good too. I liked it maybe because i love sci-fi movies it wasn't the best sci-fi movie i have seen but its not the worst either. I gave it the rating 5 because i think it deserves that much lower than that is just wrong. If you don't like sci-fi don't watch it.

column4: Lived up to my expectations...Bloody awful.
column5: Any film that is based on a book written by someone who peddles religion (scientology) is on to a big loser from the start but i was determined to have an open mind about Battlefield Earth despite the reviews. There are many many bad things about this film that i wont go into because i am sure the other reviews do that job but what what i will say is the first half hour is not that bad but from then on it rapidly descends into one of the most stupid films i have seen in a long long long.Just one example is that the humans attack the aliens by learning to fly Harrior Jump Jets!!!! John Travolta is interesting and irritating because he keeps using the same lines such as " This lousy planet" and "Rat brains". The only thing i can liken this movie to is a very poor episode of Babylon 5 or Star Trek but 3 times as long. Not the worst film i have ever seen but still it is still pants. 3 out of 10.

column4: The saga that could have been and was not
column5: Crushed to the fullest by almost all the criticism existing on this planet I have to make a song in favor of this movie and say that it is not even one of the worst films in history nor is it as bad as it looks.The film has no doubt that it has things that simply do not add up or are absurd or involuntarily comical whether due to the "rasta" look of the aliens a rather trite and unoriginal story an excessive duration and a sometimes heavy rhythm or a very improvable soundtrack and many others.But on the other hand the film is quite curious and fun in its own way. The presence of John Travolta playing a stereotyped but charismatic villain who enjoys the best dialogues and moments of the film helps a lot to the quality of a film that is not so cumbersome and compares with many current "B or Z series jejitas. Asylum roll that populate so many video store shelves. This at least has some decent Fx and I mean it they are not as crappy as they say.The prota Barry Peeper fulfills his role well. The typical sacrificed and noble hero who seeks the good and freedom of his race. It is not perfect but it is correct.And well in what is already the direction production design and such ... well that is not a big deal but it is not the worst thing I have seen it is a film that is entertaining and enjoyable if it is not It demands too much and I don't know why a clearly commercial product should be demanded of anything that failed in large part because of the bad reputation of the Scientology Church since the history of the film was written by its founder Ron L Hubbard and in large part because of the fierce specialized criticisms that circulated word of mouth that it was the worst film of the decade and that it was rubbish these two factors greatly affected the film he intended as he said in his advertising posters Become a saga.But I who am neither a professional critic nor anything I say very clearly is not the worst film in history nor of the past decade.It is simply one more science fiction film with its eccentricities defects and also its good moments and peculiarities and that in my opinion it does not deserve to be dilapidated more than other bodies that circulate around and that have even made it up to a film of worship.Thank you.

column4: Not as bad as everyone thinks.
column5: Before you believe all of the hype- give this movie a chance. It was never meant to be a serious Sci-Fi flick nor was it filmed with any serious message or intent. It was mainly written as a fun exciting and sometimes humorous thrill-ride and in that respect it is very appealing and delivers. Also the special effects are terrific (look out for dizzying camera angles and overused scene fades.) Am I the only one who liked this movie?

column4: This is a movie you ought to see.
column5: This is an entertaining film. I have seen it three times and will buy it when it becomes available on DVD.I was an early critic of the film (before it was released) because I saw character names that were not in the book. A word about the book - I have read and reread this book a number of times over the last fifteen years and I think it is teriffic. So when I saws character names like Mara that were not in the book I got on my high horse and denounced the film asserting that the producers were using the title and little else.So let me ask you... How to you condense a book that is 1200 pages long to a two hour movie? Not very easily.I think they did a good job. John Travolta was great as Terl. I look forward to a sequel.Go see this movie - you will have a great time.

column4: This movie has bewildered me for another fifty cycles...with endless options for renewal!
column5: I'm really confused as to how this movie came to be. It has a $44 million budget ($68 million in today's money) and major talent attached but the mistakes are so amateur and in such high quantity that this movie should be thrown in an incinerator and never be spoken of. But alas it was released to theaters. This movie is really baffling more than anything because of the backstory. So for that reason I would recommend this movie ironically but you should read about the production for this movie. It's really quite fascinating.

This sci-fi adventure based on L. Ron Hubbard's novel of the same name is bad but not as abysmal as its reviews and the public backlash would lead one to believe. Hubbard of course is the controversial author of `Dianetics' and the founder of the Church of Scientology of which John Travolta is a devotee. The story is supposedly allegorical of the psychological imprisonment that human beings face. The hero Johnny Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper) is thought to be Hubbard as he saw himself a savior of the human race from psychological bondage. There is probably some truth to the charges that Travolta produced this film as a tribute to Hubbard to legitimize his name. He reportedly staked $5 million of his own money to foot part of the $78 million budget. Claims that it was intended to be a recruiting film for Scientology are probably overblown. Though I have my own feelings about the danger of cults I will confine my review to the film itself.The story started out with interesting possibilities. An advanced alien race with a preoccupation with accumulating wealth invaded earth for its natural resources and pushed the human race to the brink of extinction. The humans were scattered and reverted to tribal behavior. Their daily lives were guided by myth and religious superstition. Humans that were found by the Psychlos were imprisoned and forced to work as slaves. Johnny is a bright young man known as a `Greener' because he rejects accepted ways and is always looking for greener pastures. He is captured by the Psychlos and he hatches a plot to defeat them to win the freedom of his newfound slave followers.To this point the film is fairly solid. It is tough to believe that established religions such as Christianity would have died out and that in 1000 years there would be no remnants of our technological advancement and no attempts to unite an underground resistance but I'm always willing to give sci-fi a wider berth. However once inside the prison each scene becomes less and less probable until one is left rolling one's eyes in incredulity. We have Stone Age mentality people learning to fly fighter jets in two weeks and flying gloriously into battle against an alien race that supposedly defeated the entire planet's defenses in nine minutes. Between flying lessons they teach themselves how to rig a nuclear warhead which they intend to transport to the Psychlos home planet to exterminate the entire race. Not bad for a bunch of illiterates.The acting is the biggest minus in the film. John Travolta is an inconsistent actor who can often be brilliant but is sometimes awful. His performance as Terl the Pyschlo Chief of Security is probably the low point of his career. It is as if he was trying to play Julius Caesar with Vinnie Barbarino's personality turning the character into a pompous moron. Clearly his passion for the project blinded him to how poor his performance was. Barry Pepper proved that he is not ready for leading roles with a portrayal that could serve as a clinic on overacting. Other than Forrest Whittaker who provided the only thing even close to acting the rest of the cast seemed to have been recruited from L.A. homeless shelters.Roger Christian who has proven himself a talented Art Director Set Director and Second Unit Director took an enormous budget and made it look like a TV movie. The best production credits go to the miniatures and special prop supervisors for the models of the ancient cities and the dome.This film was punished at the box office grossing less than one-third of its enormous budget. I rated this film a 4/10. It had some interesting elements a decent premise and some good visual effects but the acting was abominable and the screenplay was butchered. For most this is a film to avoid.

This is the epic movie of the year. Quality film making. I don't want to get ahead of myself but I think this is the movie of the millenium! Mind you the millenium just started but I have faith that film making will never surpass the greatness that is Travolta and his giant nose plugs.

I thought the film was much worse than it turned out. It looked interesting. Why can't space travelling aliens be less sophisticated than the tech they use?I did like the effort clearly made to make everything about the aliens alien.It did take a lot of liberties what with cavemen using C20 weapons - from rifles to Harriers to some sort of atomic bomb used to destroy a planet - but as the whole film was very kids cartoonish anyway why was it unreasonable not to expect these points to be taken with a pinch of salt.

This was the most fun I've had at the movies all year. Realize this is not a totally serious movie. It's not the Matrix and it's not Star Wars. It's more like the Fifth Element.This movie captures the feel of the book quite well including its blemishes. For example there's no way that our civilization would be nearly so intact after 1000 years (but as in the book you shouldn't believe that 1000 years have really passed; try more like 200-250). There's no way a primitive "caveman" who is thrown into a fighter simulator can become a fighter ace in less than a week. Yeah yeah. So what? Go with it.As for the stupidity / incompetence of the aliens... yes realize that Earth is a backwater dumping ground for incompetents for the Psylocks. And yes the actors use 20th century slang but let that go since we are hearing the "best translation" of their speech.To enjoy this movie you need massive suspension of disbelief or the willingness to mock it. Since the movie laughs at itself this shouldn't be as hard as it sounds. This movie succeeds on every level it was trying for and ignores everything else like realism. Just sit back and enjoy.

This Movie proves that some books are better left books and not big budget Hollywood Movies with big stars who's talents would be better left doing other things.To quote someone else "How did this stinkbomb ever get made"

I know a lot of viewers have found this movie bad but frankly I find it much better than many of the latest Science Fiction movies - even those who have got rewards.Looking away from the obvious event that makes no sense that you can find intact infrastructure particular air craft after 1000 and a nuclear device that works! then it is not too bad.What I like: Aliens here are not different from Humans. OK they are bigger stronger breath some other kind of air and drink nasty stuff. BUT they do have the same nasty habits like humans cheating greed (gold surprise!!) sex and like to dominate others. Their political system seems to be as rotten as on earth.The Aliens laugh at each other when something goes bad even when a human happen to kill one of the aliens. Hey they are rotten inside just like real bad people so we do not have to feel sorry for them when their planet is blown up.And I like that the greed make the responsible for the operation take a human to train him in their technology to make more gold which leads to his own downfall.IF the amount of years of repression had been less - and IF they had found a way to use the aliens aircraft's and tools to fight them the scenes would be less hilarious.I have watched more times and I always like when Aliens are as bad as human politicians :)

column4: This movie was fantastic for a Travolta movie
column5: This movie was a great Travolta movie. It had action comedy great special effects and more comapred to other Travolta movies. It was entertaininf to watch for a Travolta movie. I gave this movie a great grade for a Travolta movie which was 1/10. Superb Travolta movie.

column4: A Modern Day Classic: A True Pile of Awful
column5: The movie is so stupid its almost offensive but for some reason I can't stop bringing it up even 7 years after its initial release.Where do I start? Well I'll start with the obvious... The acting dialog story and the cinematography is absolutely awful; some of the worse you'll see in a motion picture. The only good thing about Battlefield Earth are some of the ideas it explores (a new beginning for humanity after a great catastrophe) the special effects sound effects and some of the lighting.The director claimed he was going for a "comic book" feel in the DVD commentary hence the massive plot holes and the 'drunk man leaning on a steep hill shooting style'. Sure... But even comic books have some degree of realism and story structure. Me thinks Roger Christian just sucks as a director.But even in the midst of this pile of awful I still find myself strangely drawn to this film. Maybe because I enjoy seeing car wrecks?

column4: When Things Got Weird Again With Travolta
column5: Franchise Pictures hit a major bump after relative success with the Bruce Willis vehicle The Whole Nine Yards with the wildly infamous Battlefield Earth which was slammed by critics went drastically over-budget due to the company's shady practises and marketing and grossed only $29.7 million at the box office out of an overall $73 million budget. Franchise's later lawsuit which would bankrupt them were over accusations of purposely inflating this film's budget.Described by Travolta himself as the Schindler's List of science-fiction films Battlefield Earth's long and outright hilarious production history basically boils down to despite what everyone thinks most people in Hollywood considering Scientologists to be a bunch of freaks and what's worse not a viable intellectual property and therefore no major studio in their right mind ever producing something akin to propaganda for the cult.Luckily for Travolta who had just failed to convince Quentin Tarantino to direct the film that Franchise pictures was neither a major studio or indeed in their right mind as they had possibly scammed some German investors with a package deal in order to finance what finally became the Roger Christian directed and the too many re-drafts to credit written Battlefield Earth for the new millennium.Now given the Scientology rub and Travolta's fanatic zeal during the marketing campaign it's easy to see why critics at the time saw this as a gross and highly ill advised vanity project cause it is and therefore see the film itself as a poorly produced wonderfully acted exceptionally cheap looking dumpster fire cause it is.However accusations of the film being dull are only warranted if you are looking for a serious film experience here which twenty million memes later would be beyond expectation.The film can be only judged realistically in 2020 by how hilarious it is as that's where it's entertainment value has now been reported to lay.Well let's run it down. The CGI is cheap as balls the matte paintings are twenty years out of date the dutch angles and colour filters are really that awkward and the acting is the most genuinely entertaining aspect of the entire movie. Travolta was and still is a true believer in this production and that's wholly evident as he leaves everything on the frame and nothing for his self-respect. Combine his ridiculous makeup and graduate level or Marlon Brando level British accent and you have a truly absurd truly camp presence that is a gift to us all.OK. screenplay. Terrible. Most novel adaptations run the risk of having dialogue sound overwrought and completely terrible and let me tell you boi about this L N***e Hubburd. Featured in Battlefield Earth is the distinctively American combination of bull**** pseudoscience and exceptionalism and such is born a British colony uprising framed within the post civil rights Pre Reagan self-help mysticism of the late seventies. In short it's truly special and uninspired and i expected nothing more from the Hubbard.Battlefield Earth is camp as all hell. It is cheap it is at times meandering and whilst meme worthy in short bursts the overwhelming mediocrity of the special effects and the storytelling make it a near unwatchable film to sit through from bell to bell as it struggles hard to maintain your attention. Maybe not for a solo watching. But I'm guarandamnnteed certain that at the right party with the right people this **** be lit.

column4: Same kind of disaster as Dune.
column5: Battlefield Earth - the book - is the same kind of literary masterpiece as Dune.Battlefield Earth - the movie - is the same kind of cinematic disaster as Dune.I honestly think that as good a job was done as COULD be done but I feel the same way about Dune. Even limiting the movie to the 1/2 half of he book there's just too much story too much character development too much of everything to fit into a single movie. It could have made a great mini-series I suppose but who knows?

column4: An endless barrage of Dutch angles and plot holes
column5: Don't let my rating fool you battlefield earth is must see classic as it is one of the greatest comedies ever made unintentionally so. This film is now so infamously terrible that it has since become a classic of the bad movie landscape. Where to begin with this well first off John Travolta redefines "acting" with one of the most bizarrely awful performances caught on camera. Imagine Tim Currys Dr Frank n further only 10 times as camp and actually meant to be taken seriously. His awkwardly forced evil laugh and constantly flailing of the arms will leave you rolling in the aisles. None of the other performances fair any better Barry Pepper is as wooden as tree and Forest Whitaker mumbles in a confused fashion as he wonders how his career stooped to this low. Cap this off with an incomprehensible plot tacky sets and costumes camera work so bad you'll get a cramp in the neck and surreal editing and bam! Battlefield Earth a masterpiece of schlock.

column4: I am still trying to find the words to tell how bad this movie was...
column5: We went to see this movie with an open mindwanting to be entertained and but what a bad film it was!! My husband slept after about 45 minutes. How could John Travolta do such a pitiful movie? It must be the Scientology connection... I did find a review that I heartily agree with: "Rita Kempley of the Washington Post pushes the envelope in denouncing the film: 'A million monkeys with a million crayons would be hard-pressed in a million years to create anything as cretinous as Battlefield Earth' she writes."

It's not the best movie in the world but the sphere is alright in this stylish science-fiction. Just a bit of fighting spirit freaky human-like aliens dark good-looking surroundings few bad scenes though but a good movie for renting. I gave it a 6.5!

column4: NOT a scientology movie... Just a great sci-fi movie.
column5: This was a great sci-fi movie. Terl and Johnny's characters were as close to their book counterparts as possible. Terl was just as arrogant and evil as he was in the book which was superb fun to see onscreen. Sure.. The book was better but books are always better. There were some parts of this movie that you REALLY had to suspend disbelief for (like the whole Harrier jet stuff) but hey... It's a movie. As for the tilted camera angles I liked them. Also the lighting was extremely well done. When the movie was showing an area that had breathe gas in the atmosphere there was a blue-ish hue all around but when there was air in the atmosphere the movie used orange-ish hues. There were also many other things that made this movie stand out. I give this movie a 9 out of 10. (I minus one for the Harrier jet stuff.)By the way I'm NOT a scientologist... I'm just a big fan of Sci-Fi movies.

column4: AV-8B Harriers with Cro Magnon pilots
column5: (spoiler included)I've seen a lot worse films than this one so the criticism has been somewhat unfair - but it is still a terribly bad movie. It is badly shot over ambitious symbolic to the point of breaking and has a story that is incoherent inconsequential and weak. Not even the special effects were anything out of the ordinary it just looked a lot like Independence Day but fuzzier dimmer and harder to follow. Near the end two really weird logic leaps are taken: the humans have degenerated to Cro Magnon (with first and last names!) but it takes them just a week to go from wooden spears to AV-8B Harrier jets (that function perfectly after a thousand years of unuse). When the dome is finally destroyed and falls down it's enough for the humans to lie down on the ground to survive - but the debris hits all the psychlos standing up. Hmmm... Several other questions arise: if gold is valuable to psychlos as well isn't it strange that they haven't scavenged the Earth for this precious metal once they learned that humans also favored gold? It wouldn't be too great an effort to realize that there must be gold deposits here and there and from there to assume that Fort Knox and such places would be empty before long isn't too difficult. And what of the nuclear weapons (that can blow up an entire planet) that are still lying around waiting for someone to use. If Jonnie took all his knowledge from the psychlo learning machine it's safe to assume that the psychlos know about the effects of nuclear weapons and would at some point taken a detailed look at the human arsenal (because Jonnie suddenly knows how to arm a device). They just left it at that? I don't get it.But there's another a lot more serious hole in this story: Travolta's evil psychlo character Terl states that it took the psychlos 9 minutes to conquer Earth and that all the knowledge the human race had couldn't help them - so Jonnie Tyler can't expect to beat the psychlos. And yet he and a band of degenerated cavemen topple the psychlo reign in just a week using almost exclusively human technology. They learn to fly Harriers so well that not only do they not crash - they actually gain air superiority over a species that conquered the fairly advanced human race in 9 minutes. Whoa! That's really something.Another question that pops in to my head is this: if the psychlos were to conquer the Earth in 9 minutes that would mean that they are a helluva lot more advanced than us - I mean taking over a planet in nine minutes is basically landing and just claiming it. But I see nothing that points to the fact that they should have been thousands of years ahead of us - ray guns and the giant dome doesn't impress me and spacecraft that can be downed with a sidewinder missile - pfft! Naahhh... to make a positive impression on me this film would have had to be reworked so fundamentally there would be no point in it having the same title as L. Ron Hubbard's novel in the first place. I expect a reasonable amount of logic even in a movie such as this. As it is "Waterworld" is more intelligent - and infinitely more entertaining.

column4: Quite possibly the worst movie ever....
column5: I'll be straightforward. This movie was horrible. The plot was weak and overused. The writing was like that of a mentally damaged 3 year old. The camera was tilted at an angle and it was almost all in blue and black or green and black reminding one even more of seasickness than the movie itself. The psychlos are terrible sort of a homeless (dirty)-rostafarian (dreadlocks)-conehead (coneheaded)-Klingon (take a guess stupid)-kiss costume wearing (stage platform boots about 3 feet high)-Rob Zombie impersonator(they really do look like Rob)- with a HUGE package (I mean seriously they must have modeled them after horse penises they're the only intimidating thing about the aliens). There are more plot holes than actual plot and they're usually pretty obvious. These aliens are supposed to rule the universe but they aren't quite as smart as a below-average rock. Also there were blatant badly done rip-off's of scenes in other movies noticably the 'lobby scene' in "the Matrix" and the 'death star trench scene' from "Star Wars". This made the whole movie ludicrous and just plain stupid.However this movie did have several good points. One the end. This was probably the best part of the movie. Not that the ending to the movie was any better filmed/acted/written but that it was good when the movie ended. Also though it was unintentional the movie was hilarious. If it had been billed as a comedy it would have been somewhere approaching first-rate. I rarely stopped laughing except to point out what NEW idiocy was on screen. Well that's about it for the good.Finally I recommend seeing it once and on the big screen but preferably not in theaters. Wait until it's on video then show it on one of those small projectors. After all we don't want to give these morons the idea we actually liked it.

Im a huge fan of this movie. Its really fun to watch and i say that as an intelligent person having scored a really high IQ speaking 8 languages having a PhD in medicine.Critics hate this movie for some reason. Sure i understand that some part are truly badly executed like the scene where group is taken out for mining tests where some cavemen attack and like in 20 seconds after a short speech the pledge their life to a man a leader that the just met and they will obey everything he wants. Also its really fun when they find a nuclear bomb and open it up after 1000 years and its operational and they fiddle with the trigger and the bomb is making all kinds of warning noises. Really nukes do that didn't you know. Also amazing that they had electricity after 1000 years in that building and of course the Harriers a marvel of human engeneering lasting a 1000years with filled tanks.Yes some loopholes in the plot but the acting from Mr Travolta is amazing and of course his co-partner in crime Mr Whitaker one of my absolutely favorite black actors does an superamazing job in this movie.The aliens are surely somewhat Klingon-looking but i think there are quite drastic differences. They are much smarter than Klingons and highly profitminded and much funnier walking. I truly enjoy their hunt for profit since it very much resembles human hunt for profit. My own observations of todays world is that profit nowadays conquers altruism and true philanthrophy.One really fun plothole that i think everyone else has missed it that leader is taught maths from a completely different extraterrestial life form but the math is having earth symbols and number format from 1 to 10. Fun. And B. But i have watched this movie several times and loving it every time.

I honestly don't understand how so many thing could go wrong with one movie. The lackluster cast could have put on a decent film especially with the help of the experienced and under-recognized supporting actor Barry Pepper. After a triumph in a supporting role in Saving Private Ryan he takes on a goofy character in this film. Travolta is just too old and recognizable to be an alien. He should just stick to playing the shallow villain in budget action movies.As for the actual content of the film it would have been better had they made it less Sci-Fi and more like a dark action-drama. Deeper meaning would have been nice here. As for the special effects they were just unnecessary. Maybe they should have taken that money and put some into hiring a capable director and a competent cinematographer.As it stands now this is just a weak film to be re-run every once in a while for those geeks who just can't get enough of looking at things flying about with little purpose.

better stay away from this movie. I went to see it because of John Travolta and I've never seen a bad Travolta film... until now. Improbable bleak and basically bad. The plot didn't make sense - the make-up was so unimpressive... I was very disappointed that I'd spent the $6.50 and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

column4: Except for the script I'd probably have enjoyed this movie...
column5: The acting was good. The special effects were well done worth seeing. The plot was OK (not very original). The dialogue was AWFUL.I never read the novel but after seeing the movie and hearing the awful lines I DO want to read it--only because I can't believe that this dialogue was in a best selling novel.I believe that with a more intelligent script this movie would have been enjoyable. I gave it 2/10.

What's the point? But I must.Everyone else who has ripped on this movie has already done so eloquently. I just wanted to add my voice.This movie sucks on deep deep levels; on every level of film-making possible. It's not even fun to laugh at. (But that's mainly because the Scientologists were watching me in the theater and they were scribbling my name in their files so they could either convert me or crush me.)But seriously people who hated this movie are you with me? He doesn't look like a bad alien' and then I get kind of scared. But at least he's fatter than me.'Really it's pointless to mention but the F/X in this movie are soooooooo bad. The laser blasts look like they're right out of a late seventies/early eighties television show. Except it's 2000 so it's not kitschy.Yawn. Weep.

column4: It is so bad that it is almost good
column5: Battlefield Earth is one of the most infamous films of all time. Battlefield Earth was intended to be a big box office blockbuster for the summer of 2000. Obviously it was not. Battlefield Earth was PANNED by literally everyone and is often considered one of the worst films of all time. Do I think so? Well..... more on that later. Battlefield Earth is based off of the novel of the same name which was written by L. Ron Hubbard who is the founder of scientology. Even I don't even know what scientoloy is and personally I could care less. After the book was released the author wanted a film adaptation to be made. Well John Travolta was a scientologist and for years and years has been wanting to do this film. So this film was a passion project. The film had lots of merchandise and was really hyped up but upon release failed. The film is directed by Roger Christian who has not directed anything really notable (besides this film) but has worked as Set Director for the Star Wars films. The film stars John Travolta (who also produced this film) Barry Pepper (Saving Private Ryan and The Green Mile) and Forest Whittaker.The evil aliens known as the Psychlos invaded Earth 1000 years ago and now in the year 3000 humans are endangered. Basically human hero gets captured and eventually makes an attempt in defeating the Psychlos who are looking for gold on Earth and whatnot.For years I have avoided this film because why would I want to torture myself and watch a film with this much negative reception? When it came to watching this film I decided to just turn my brain off for once and not view this film under a critical lense. I will admit that it was hard to do (with the obvious flaws being very....well.....obvious). With that being said I do not think that Battlefield Earth is the worst film of all time. Yes it is a bad film but not a bad enough film to make me wish that I have never watched it. It is bad in an interesting sort of way. I am entertained by how bad it is. So the obvious negatives. The camera work is really really bad. Everything (or a very very large majority) of the shots are shot at an angle. Why? No clue. It is just very very strange. The story and script are just as equally bad with plot holes and what not. There is no build up to anything in this film and stuff just kind of happens. The Psychlos are very dumb in this film and the whole plot is just really dumb and in itself. Now that is where most of my negativity ends. Everything else about this film while does not make for a really good film makes for an entertaining sort of film. Well somewhat entertaining. The acting is not great overall and would not typically be classified as good. John Travolta gives a really over the top performance but I am somewhat entertained by it. Barry Pepper as our hero while not a good hero due to not being written very well appears to be trying really hard with what he has been given. The special effects themselves range from mediocre to well...... that did not age well. The practical makeup effects are pretty neat despite the Psychlos looking butt ugly. The whole color scheme of blue and gray does not really bother me whatsoever. The music for the film is not bad which is strange because I do personally think that everyone who watched this film decided that this is the worst film ever and critiqued everything like the music without giving it a listen. Sure it is pretty standard but if I am to think of anything in this film that is not terrible this would be it.Battlefield Earth is not the worst film of all time. Far from it. Sure for a big budget film it really blows. When it comes to the big flaws it is really bad. Had it had a better script and story I think the film would have been much better.
