column4: Read the book saw the movie both stunk.
column5: The only fanatics who would vote this a "10" must be scientologists. Of course being members of the L. Ron Hubbard(tm) Cult of Greed and Hate is already enough reason to doubt their thinking.It was bad it was really bad and it was never meant to be "camp" like some folks claim. It simply stunk.Not many books which are turned into movies survive the process or even come close to being as good as the original book. I have never seen a book "Improved" when it became a movie with very few exceptions. It takes exceptional books exceptional actors and exceptional directors. This example lacks all three. In this case the movie is far worse than the book.Maybe the single worst movie of the last 100 years.
This is such a bad movie that it's actually amusing to watch.The French word 'navet' is perfectly adequate here.

column4: A black hole could not suck more than this film.
column5: I can't really add anything new here that others haven't already said. Heard all the negative reviews of it but saw it out of curiosity anyway. How bad could it possibly be right?Oh...the horror....

I've heard all those bad critics about this movie but I decided to take a look and see for myself. Now I believe to all those who don't love this movie. It is so obvious why.We've got director Roger Christian who won Oscar and we also have here two great actors: John Travolta and Forest Whitaker (Travolta nominated and Whitaker won Oscar). No one can't say that they aren't stars cause they are. I'm really disappointed with Whitaker's performance. He is so bad that I have no words. Travolta on other hand never really cared about this role. He did his part as professional and took his money. Maybe he realized too that there is no reason to act good in such a lousy movie. Barry Pepper is in range with Whitaker. Equally bad. But in Pepper's case I had no real expectations.Special effects. What special effects? Whole movie was made so bad on that and on all other fields. Probably all the money went for securing Travolta's name in this project. But even without special effects it is possible to make a good movie. This isn't that case cause it hasn't got good story. From potentially OK script this turned to a disaster. Disaster on all levels. Red lights. Don't watch this movie. Or watch it and smile.But maybe we should all look at brighter side of this project. So many nominations and wins for this one. Of course Razzie Awards dominate. In this case I agree with them. Fully deserved.

column4: John Travolta liked the book and wanted to make a movie.
column5: Gone with the wind The Exorcist Saving Private Ryan Schindler's List...Battlefield Earth. A brief summary of some of my favorite movies.I admit when I saw this movie on opening day I thought some of the elements in the films story were a little ridiculous. The flight simulator the fact that the humans were a little slow on what the function of things really were but the idea of taking back the planet wasn't so terrible and neither was the carrying out of that idea.The acting was fine. The SFX and the Art direction are not as bad as some say with sixty million dollars how could anything look cheap. I read a criticism on the dialogue what do we know about how aliens talk anyway? Aliens have personalities and attitudes and they have to put them to use they're in a business to make money and rule the universe treachery is a way of life.I recently started reading the book and it cleared up a few things in the film it's disappointing that the producers wanted a 2hr action-SiFi movie instead of what L. Ron Hubbard wrote in his book but it doesn't take away too much of the story and is still worth your time.For the bored at heart and those who thought is was stupid go back to watching made for TV movies that the have brains acting directing and the same moral point and cliched story line(at least THIS was original) with a box of tissues. For those who aren't so quick to insult a group of well established film makers who made what they KNOW to be a good movie(or else they wouldn't have wasted they're time making it do you think John Travolta needs another twenty million dollars to waste a year of his life to make a crappy movie?) see it. It doesn't play so well on the small screen but it's still not a waste of your time.

Someone passed some rumor that battlefield earth was so violent that scientists complained that it demeaned humanity. Sure it demeaned humanity but it is not violent at all. It treats humans like animals. 'Man' animal to be precise. I would be lying if I said that an average human was anymore than the animal portrayed in this movie but still this movie is not so subtle. It seems to be created solely for the purpose of displaying that idea. But the good news is that humans do end up winning. Battlefield earth may not be one of the worst films ever made but it is still pretty bad. You can watch it if you have nothing better to do at all.

column4: It's not Thanksgiving but here's a fat turkey.
column5: It's really hard to picture John Travolta sitting with his fellow producers and loving this movie. I'll warn you right now this one is the most pathetic movies I have ever wasted two hours of time on. There is no feature that isn't a rip off from elsewhere the special effects are very subpar and the plot is so terrible that it is hard to bring myself to even remember it. It's the "Little Caveman That Could" set in the future. It wouldn't have been half as bad if the movie hadn't taken itself so darn seriously.It's too late for me but save yourself the ticket price and stare at a wall for two hours. You'll thank yourself.

I do wonder if John Travolta and Forest Whittaker ever catch up and discuss the travesty that is this science fiction film. It's so unbelievable given how supremely great these veteran actors have become.The set design special effects and costumes are pretty laughable even for their time. The writing direction and acting are overall poor resulting in a very mediocre narrative. The only thing keeping you going during the film is this "waiting" for something of meaning to happen while simultaneously being dumbfounded by how such a high budget film could have been made with so little forethought.

OK this was not by any means a great film but to see people comparing this to something like "Leonard 6" or "Caddyshack 2" is a bit of a stretch. The plot was thin but the effects were very very good and I liked the green/blue aura of the film. I sure didn't care about Barry Pepper's character and he had no charisma but Travolta was so over-the-top that is what made this film somewhat fun. And people when you ask why Cavemen learn to fly jets as silly as it is it's called a movie. Fantasy. Look into it.

column4: a "1" is not a low enough rating!
column5: Battlefield Earth is modern-day Ed Wood with a larger budget plain and simple. It is truly amazing to think that anyone involved in the production could have ever thought it would be a good even watchable film. The story gives new meaning to the word "inane." The acting is laughable. And the production design is basically throwing a lot of dust all over the place. But the worst offender is the direction. Roger Christian uses different angles close-ups and slow-motion to emphasize his "drama." All it does is make everything on screen look completely pathetic. Battlefield Earth is only fun to watch if you like watching bad movies to laugh at them. Even then you can probably find something more worth your time. This movie isn't so bad it's good. It's just plain awful.

Come on people. You can say this movie is a pure example of a Hollywood FIASCO. But can all of the people involved in the making of this film be that brainless? If you decide to see it watch is as you wood Commando. This has to be slapstick. Most of or all of the characters in this movie are caricatures. The script is a collection of black humor skits. It acts serious but I was hyperventilating i.e. gasping for air. It was non-stop laughter. Can anyone believe this story to be plausible? Does anybody think that the scriptwriter was using any authentic creditable sources in the world of science? I can see how this movie might upset some people but that's only if it's taken seriously. Then it would be straight up trash! Otherwise enjoy the satire the absurdities this absolute preposterous farce of a movie. I am a bit curious about what the genuine followers of Scientology really think...?....

I have to admit I somewhat enjoyed this movie. There are some movies that are so BAD they're GOOD and I guess I would put this movie in that category ("Cobra" with Sylvester Stallone is another good example). I can enjoy how creatively BAD it is. The bit about the humans teaching themselves to fly sophisticated jet aircraft in a short span of time...well...yeah that is a bit out there but there are tons of movies that require you to suspend your disbelief in order to enjoy them. I suppose I see this movie in that vein. Put aside the clear departures from reality and enjoy it for what it is. It's a bizarre strange tale but it held my interest. Obviously it got produced and distributed so SOMEONE thought it was worth putting out there. If you're in the mood for a goofy creatively bad movie you could certainly do a lot worse. I'd give it a 5.

column4: Special effects are only a disguise for this boring film.*
column5: Battlefield Earth had everything that I liked for a science fiction film.Great set designsgood alien makeupand alot of special effects.Now comes the actingdirection and storyline.Wellthe film doesn't have any."Battlefield Earth" happens to be one of those boring sci-fi films that has to hide it's true mark by adding alot of visual effects and happens to be one of those films that had me leaving the theater asking myself if the eight dollars I spent was well worth.According to this reviewit was not.Based on the novel by L.Ron Hubbardthe film concerns a bunch of humans in a futuristic 3000A.D. These humans are enslaved by aliens that resemble the klingons from the Star Trek films.John Travolta plays Terl.A villain in the film that seemed to bore me rather than intersest me.I am not even going to mention the other actors or characters because from what I figuredwhat's the point?"Battlefield Earth" is a boring film with alot of corniness that I did not care for.

I love sci-fi fantasy and generally odd movies. What's odd about this is that it was ever made John Travolta or no. A little humor might've helped though I doubt it. A sterling example that an overly expensive film need not be any good .. at all. Train of thought; Travolta a video camera a few actors and a _real_ script would most likely be infinitely more rewarding. But Travolta really wanted to make this film as well as the upcoming sequel so all hope probably _is_ lost. It is disturbing to watch otherwise formidable actors become trapped in semi-religious rubbish such as this L. Ron Hubbard "script".

One of the best black comedies I've seen. An exquisite satire on the human condition. This film is surely up there with Dr. Strangelove. Funny funny stuff.Travolta and Whitaker simply superb as two iconic doofuses of the ruling class. Barry Pepper's disciplined dead-pan approach as the "man animals" (humans) visionary revolutionary leader contrasted and complemented the other two main leads performances and the camp of his human followers.I've seen this film several times now over the years since its release and never tire of it. Definitely a 10.Surprised that other reviewers think this is somehow meant to be in any sense a "serious" tale. Anyway either Travolta is a genius or despite his best efforts he managed to Forrest Gump his way to a classic of major proportions.

column4: I laughed (when I shouldn't) I cried (for sitting through it); it moved me (to the bathroom)
column5: I recently saw this film for the second time. I have to say that there was great potential in the story but this one flopped flat on its face. By sticking to the overdramatic wordage of the penny-a-page hack Hubbard it destroyed any possibility of connecting with a general audience. I was fortunate enough to watch with a former Scientologist who got some great laughs for the apparent propoganda in the film. Besides the horrible overacting and that crap-lousy faux British accent of Travolta's I couldn't get past the major plot holes to get into the film. Some of the ones I noticed that haven't been discussed much on here: 1) Johnny uses a learning machine that teaches him Psychlo language and culture. Yet he discusses "Euclidian Geometry". Why is Euclid an Earthling discussed on the machine? 2) The "man-animals" seem to have no written language (evidenced by the lack of writing other than primitive cave drawings) yet by studying Psychlo culture he can suddenly read books in English in the Denver Library and understand a complicated manual for a nuclear device. 3) Even getting past finding a WORKING flight simulator these machines do not instruct those who have never flown. Understanding the hover systems as well as weaponry of a Harrier in a few days is inconceivable. 4) The Psychlos have been searching for and mining gold for 1000 years. Apparantly in that time they did no research on the subject. Magically in his short time in the Denver library Johnny picks a book which discusses the huge gold reserves at Ft. Knox. 5) Travolta's character (like I ever worried about remembering his name) questions why the gold has been put into bars yet never questions how!And there are so many more. Put this movie up there with "Look Who's Talking Too" as painful to watch a fairly talented actor sinking like a stone.

I can honesty say that I have never experienced anything quite like this. It was an unforgettable experience. Unfortunately. I could only watch half the movie let me explain why.Imagine being stuck in a tiny lift with morbidly obese man who has eaten lots of eggs and suffers from extreme flatulence. Imagine that he has neither showered nor changed his clothes for the past decade. Now imagine having to give him a bath in the lift with your tongue.Not nice is it. Well I can honestly say I would prefer that to having to see Battlefield Earth. I have never had the misfortune to experience such an insult not just to cinema but to the world of entertainment and humanity. This film was a complete load of cretinous Scientologist rubbish; I could have made a far superior movie from the change in my pocket.Whatever you do do not watch this film. In fact don't even go near it don't look at the website don't consider it in the video store don't download or buy it. Trust me if you do the horror of having to watch it will haunt you for the rest of your days.

column5: Being subject to this film should be a crime.This movie is real garbage. Like not "oh it's not great" but I mean actually garbage.You shouldn't watch this mess of a movie. If you can call it anything more than a high school film project.I felt physically ill and angry towards every scene. From the first hour of Barry pepper running. To John Travolta's hand prosthetic. column4: Cheesy silly weird fantastic. bad. GREAT!
column5: People expected a lot more from the support cast and Barry Pepper doesn't have the screen presence to role. He's a sexless emotionless figure and so is his love interest int he film - who everyone takes orders from late in the film apparently because she is Barry Pepper's squeeze.It's a Scientology film starring one of Hollywood's big scientologist actors.It has Ray Bradbury Theatre level effects and sub-Ray Bradbury story/dialogue. Basically expect some perfectly adequate effects for television but ofr a blockbuster sci-fi (which this despite its aspiration NEVER was) don't get your hopes up.The plot holes are legion but the narrative keeps moving along at a steady pace. The final battle is fairly trite with some of the worst models/effects effects giving the film the aesthetic quality of a 1970's disaster movie.*IF* you can make it past these glaring flaws and enjoy *CHEESE* and silly science fiction this film definitely has the ability to provide a great deal of pleasure.Travolta is as good as Travolta ever was... Forest Whittaker is walking or limping through his performance but still provides a good deal of comic relief. The heavily shoed Psychlos are quite delicious as they back stab and torture each other mercilessly.

column4: Rather than talk about the movie here's a recipe for a peach cobbler
column5: Method STEP 1 Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Grease a baking dish with a little butter then lay the drained peach slices in the base. Sprinkle with 2 tbsp of the sugar and the ground ginger and set aside.STEP 2 Tip the flour remaining sugar baking powder cinnamon and a pinch of salt into a food processor. Whizz until combined then add the cubes of butter pulse until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs then add the egg and continue to blitz until it comes together to make a thick dough.STEP 3 Spoon the dough in dollops on top of the peaches creating a good covering but leave some gaps for the dough to spread into. Sprinkle with a little caster sugar then bake for 40 mins until golden. Serve with scoops of vanilla ice cream.

column4: I wish people would develop their own opinions.
column5: I don't really think that most of the people that tore this movie apart really watched the film. They were immediately impressed how it has been declared the worst film ever and just saw a pretty picture on their televisions while claiming how terrible it was.I also think that anyone who connects this film with Scientology should be smacked really hard with a copy of Dianetics. I am no Scientology advocate but the book was just another of L. Ron Hubbard's novels. That's it. Travolta made this movie as a homage to his mentor not to promote his religion.And of course the movie is rife with plot holes. Unfortunately the story is too deep and complex to make a 3 hour movie complete let alone a 90 minute one. The universe in the book in far more expansive and Johnny's plan of taking back the planet is far more in depth. The difference between books being made into film and original screenplays is that the screenplay is written with such time limitations in mind. Every book that has been made into film has had plot holes and missing elements.All of that said the only truly bad part of Battlefield Earth is the cinematography but really only one aspect of such. Too often the camera seemed tilted for no other reason than to depict a chaotic scene and this just did not come across well.The acting was done very well the sets and special effects were for the most part done well. The costumes were not perfect but I am sure it is not easy to make a 6 foot man appear to be an 8 foot alien.I understand there are going to be some people that truly don't like this movie. But for the rest of you please watch it for yourself and don't listen to other people.

column4: The most loose direct book adaptation I've ever seen..
column5: Well this is an ok movie. It's not great I don't regret spending $4.50 to see it at a matinee time but I would of regretted $8. Of course I'm not HAPPY I spent it either.. I recently finished the book (3 days ago as of 5/12/00) and saw it mostly because of that (or vice-versa take your pic). Needless to say the cliche works: "The book was better". How's that: a book beating a movie in action scenes. Perhaps the sequel will redeem it in this department (this is only about 1/3 of the book) since the best action sequence the fight with the Brigantes is in that chunk.

column4: One of the best S/F comedies since Spaceballs
column5: WARNING *****THIS IS A S/F COMEDY***** If you try and take it seriously you have missed the point. It is a comic book transferred to the big screen. NO GORE violence is implied and there are no car chases but a lot of dry humour and great puns are evident.The movie is filled with bits from other previous S/F films presented in a comedic fashion. See how many you can spot.Don't believe the low rating that resulted in the general public expecting a "serious film" like a Star Wars or one of the many Star Treks. You know a realistic S/F ;-)

Yes the tilted camera angles are annoying but not enough to ruin the film. Likewise the sub-par special effects are laughable but hardly enough to make it a bad movie. There is enough going on to keep me from getting bored and the school play level acting doesn't put me off. All of these are problems but together they wouldn't be enough to put this film on the bottom 100 films of all time.The one all-encompassing thing that really kills Battlefield Earth is the enormous amount of stupidity that is omnipresent through all of the 118 minutes. A few examples of said stupidity (SPOILER ALERT):According to the film all the well trained soldiers of earth lasted a total of 9 minutes against the Psyclos but ragtag team of cavemen beat them with our technology.The Psyclos know about the level of technology humans had before the invasion but still think humans are only good for manual labour.They have lived on earth for 1000 years and still have not bothered to learn our language or teach us theirs.Twentyeth century weapons have been lying around in a bunker for 1000 years without becoming even slightly rustyThe humans don't know math such as what a triangle is but have still managed to build a complicated gate for the wall around the villageThe list goes on but I don't want to write down the entire movie. That's it if the plot was less stupid this could have been an OK film.

All the Scientology aside L. Ron Hubbard wrote a couple of decent SciFi novels. "Battlefield Earth" (the book) is a decent space opera a little naive but quite humorous and a good enough way to while away quite a few hours (the book is long but the story flows nicely to be tied up with quite a good ending).A shame that the same cannot be said for the film. First of all the acting is simply atrocious - no-one repeat no-one is believable. Adding to this is that in shortening the book to fit in the obligatory 90 minutes almost all of the important/exciting/interesting bits of the story were ignored or at best changed beyond recognition.I'd still recommend the book but as for the film avoid enriching the church's coffers! Really really not worth it!

column4: Why does everyone bash this movie?
column5: I can't understand why so many people bash this movie. I understand that it's not the greatest science-fiction movie ever made but myself and many people I know find this movie great fun. Some of the acting may be corny but I find it has great action good effects and a good plot. Also it has local boy Barry Pepper who is becoming a very good actor and a pretty good job by John Travolta. So in saying I don't care what any lousy critic or the general public think of this movie. I find it a great watch.

I have seen a lot of movies in my time. I have liked a lot of movies in my time. But I have also been searching for the worst movie ever for a long time this fits the bill perfectly. Without breaking a sweat or batting an eye I can say that this is by far the worst serious movie ever made. See it once I highly recommend the experience to all the masochistic moviegoers out there.

column4: Served as the inspiration for The Force Awakens
column5: This turkey spoke jive to Jar Jar Abrams and inspired The Farce Awakens. Here humans find a jet that is a millennium old find that it still flies and learn to command it in under five minutes (screw YOU Top Gun!). In The Farce Awakens a homeless dumpster diving girl finds the millennium falcon languishing in the desert and takes it into the galaxy fuel maneuvering and charting and all.!

column4: The very worst movie I have ever seen!
column5: While searching for a movie that I could rent. I came across this movie that I never heard of before. Figuring that Travolta was in it i assumed that it would definitely be worth watching. Boy was I wrong. I cannot believe that Travolta would allow himself to be in a movie like this after he read the script. The whole movie did not make any sense what-so-ever. Not only that but I could not figure out what the plot of this movie was about. It just never made sense right from the beginning. Half way through the movie I was praying that miraculously it would become interesting. My prayers were not answered. Please save your $3.50 and buy popcorn with it or rent another movie.

column4: I wish it was possible to give this movie a NEGATIVE number
column5: A movie must be Truly bad to deserve a 1 rating from me. Battlefield Earh is one that qualifies.I am a fan of Travolta. He is excellent in Pulp Fiction. He is good in Face Off. His really early success was Saturday Night Fever and he was brilliant in that movie. I even rather enjoyed him in Broken Arrow. However Battlefield Earth shows that Travolta is capable of making a piece of crap too.The script was lame the acting was Awful the special effects were not much better but they were the "highlight" of the "film." I am sure that everybody stank too even though we couldn't smell them (at least they LOOK like they stink).Anyway do yourselves a favor and avoid this turd like the plague.BTW about this being a great book I am sure it is a pretty good one. But L. Ron Hubbard to me is just as nuts as all those other Scientology nuts (including Mr. Travolta).

column4: For once I actually agree with the critics on this one
column5: This is one of the very few movies that I agreed with the critics on. This movie did suck. I admit I wanted to see this movie when it came out because it looked good the effects looked great and the story sound interesting. However I didn't get to see it during it's theatrical run at the movies but I did see it when it debuted on HBO. What I thought was gonna to be a rip-roaring sci-fi adventure turned out to be a sci-fi dud. John Travolta was totally wrong for this movie he shouldn't have acted in it but he should have only produced it an nothing more. Thank God they haven't tried to make a sequel out of this one because this definitely does not need a sequel.

The movie was unbearable I would have rather been stuck with a 1000 needles than sit through that movie again. Battlefield Earth was a mistake a glitch you could say. The movie was so excruciatingly painful that I felt like throwing up. About halfway through the movie I asked myself if this was suppose to be a comedy or not. I found myself asking the questions Did they really mean to make this movie? Are they joking? As the movie finished I cheered and clapped out of utter celebration that it was done. I do wish two things though that I could have given this movie a lower rating 1 does not even justify how bad this movie was. Also if I could have got my money back.

column4: It has to be the worst idea someone could come up with.
column5: This is the greatest compilation of elements of a horrible movie put together. We can start with the cast that with the exception of Travolta and Whitaker has no acting abilities whatsoever. The acting for this movie was exceptionally bad with actors that have no emotion at all.The screenplay author wrote simply the poorest lines ever. It is unbelievable that Travolta agreed to say such empty and childish lines in a movie. The extremely predictable plot is also something that shows how poorly this film was made. People this century should know better than to have shallow plots such as this one. The movie drags for two hours. Very boring. The special effects certainly did NOT reflect the huge budget of this film. Take for instance the part that Terl character of Travolta throws the "man-animal" down an abyss. I found it incredible the obviousness of the screen on the scene. (Don't forget to notice the bad acting in that scene too.) To topple it up the names places histories were extremely unbelievable. Yes it is a fiction but Artificial Intelligence and even Lord of the Rings are more believable than this! In every aspect this is one of the worst displays of human talent yet. But hey life goes on. Let the Matrixes and Godfathers come. Why waste time with the sadness of Hollywood when the spectacles of image and sound are right there at Blockbuster right next to the Battlefield Earth tape which by the way needs some dusting.

column4: One of the worst Movies I've ever sat through.
column5: I'm not one to walk out of a movie once I've started watching it but in retrospect if I could pick 2 hours of my life I could have back...I would have preferred to never see this movie. Biggest load of garbage I've seen produced in mainstream theatre. This is below a "B" movie. Ugh. Makes me sick just thinking about it.

column4: Good movie. render the book well
column5: The film stick mostly to the book except for the timeline witch was shorter in the movie. All of the important event where there. Some changes have been made to ease the production and to allow easy editing of the story.I think the actors where good and credible. Some characters weren't deep enough but this is the same in the book. No character evolved or changed except for Ker and that isn't obvious.The special effects where good but nothing new there. It reminds me of ID4. The futurist landscape is looking good. The aliens weren't alien enough for my taste. It's as if they wanted us to see who were the actors.The music wasn't intrusive but rendered the tension of the situations well.Overall I enjoyed the film. The story was entertaining and we could easily relate to the characters. Most of the time if I see a movie made from a book I have read before I'm disappointed. This wasn't the case. In my book they made a movie worth seeing

I'm not quite sure why this movie is despised by so many perhaps because of Hubbard's Scientology stuff. Battlefield Earth of course has nothing to do with Scientology it is what it is.The novel and the movie are both in all honesty simply a 50s style space opera. It's not supposed to be deep it's not supposed to be realistic even it's just supposed to be fun. And it is.

column4: Taken in context a decently fun movie
column5: I went into the theater to watch Battlefield Earth with TWO things in mind: don't expect it to follow the novel (which I'd read in the early 1980s) and suspend disbelief. And guess what? I enjoyed it. The basic spirit of the book was followed... that mankind could unite and fight against insurmountable odds for the freedom of their world. The acting was quite good though I admit the script could have been better. John Travolta seems to excel at playing fun exciting villains. Mind you... the Suspension of Disbelief is important... if you hated Independence Day simply because you couldn't handle civilians learning to fly F/A-18s in 2 days and the world's most incompatible computer the Macintosh being able to interact with an alien system then you won't be able to handle certain things in Battlefield Earth. But if your mind is that closed why are you a sci-fi fan to begin with? :) Simply put taken in context Battlefield Earth is a fun film.
In the vein of a cult classic. Don't take every movie so seriously sit back and enjoy. John Travolta is great.

column4: If you're a sucker for post-apocalypse and camp...
column5: So I'll get it out of the way and say it right now: Scientology is at the very least "problematic" and at its worst downright dangerous. So please take this as a review of the *film* and not the backers.So here's the thing. This film? It's hilarious. It's often unintentionally so but come on folks.* 9 foot tall alien John Travolta with dreadlocks * 1000 year old jets (which failed to stop the alien invasion when brand new) used by mostly untrained humans to kill all the aliens * Aliens with a "learning machine" voiced by a depressed "all my other fellow aliens are extinct sigh" character * Purple everywhere * Ruins!It's actually kinda great. Most of the premise is ridiculous but the costumes and set-pieces are great and a lot of the acting is actually dead on at least for the film this IS (and not the one it meant to be).And say what you want about John Travolta but he's actually totally great in this film as an absolute #^%@head arrogant alien and his lackey is equally well played.So yeah conceptually? Totally ridiculous. And the lead "human" actor? Not fantastic. But this is actually a totally enjoyable post-apocalyptic campy-as-hell film.Now I'm a huge sucker for post-apocalyptic settings and when I tell people *how* much of a sucker I am for them I use this film as an example. "I like post apocalyptic films so much that I like BATTLEFIELD EARTH!"If you go into this film looking for a compelling serious science fiction film addressing deep philosophical issues you're going to come away very disappointed.But if you're looking for drinking-game fuel or a lovely combination of post-apocalypse and unintentional hilarity? Yeah this is a great film for you.

column4: The failure of religion on the screen
column5: One thing that seems missing from the deserved derision this movie was subjected to on this site was the recognition that Travolta made it because of his religious zeal. Of course it didn't help that the acting was awful the direction absent and the special effects well off the state of the art. But religion almost without exception makes lousey film - remember the Greatest Story Ever Told? The reason is that realism goes out of the window but is not replaced by humour or horror or even the avant garde. Its replaced by homage. Battlefield Earth was a hymn of praise to L. Ron Hubbard. And it was quite the most ghastly film I have seen.

Very Disappointed movie I would have thought that they at least try to follow the original storyline a bit closer. I am not looking forward to the 2nd movie (but I will probably watch it). ps The book is superb (read it several times)

column4: man oh man where to begin....
column5: OK let's get this turd out in the open:Mankind had been enslaved for 1000 years by aliens & humans have reverted back to basically stone-age mentalities (although some people speak like they live in the middle ages while others sound like they live in modern day L.A.) & yet... 1. in 1000 years electricity & computers (like flight simulators & overhead projectors) still work somehow & fighter jets still have jet fuel in them. Also books & paper are slightly dusty but perfectly preserved (in Denver no less which I'm pretty sure gets a lot of damp weather.) 2. these stone-age humans who live in caves & have never seen any technology can master in one week advanced weapons & flight simulations enough to defeat the "superior" (dumb-ass) alien race at dogfights & combat. (also how did they learn modern-day combat lingo???) Apparently in the year 2000 when the aliens showed up they conquered earth in 9 minutes. 1000 years later !cavemen! can beat them & destroy their home planet with only like 3 people dying. 3. why do the aliens make Barry Pepper so smart & then give him access to all of their records & passwords & equipment etc? They just want him to mine gold so why not just teach him only to swing a pick ax which the human slaves are already doing? 4. why is the dialog so stupid? I read an earlier review that said he watched the movie on cable so he wondered if he missed anything. Let me tell you buddy you didn't. At one point Forrest Whitaker said something like "crap-head" & they seem to think "rat-brain" is a hard-core insult. 5. the best the production design team could come up with for alien alcohol is... glowing green liquid with a straw in it? Seriously this movie was made in the year 2000 & that's the best you could do? 6. the same goes for the special effects. They're terrible! This movie cost $70 million. It also looks like it was shot on video. & what's with all the dutch angles? There's only 1 or 2 straight shots in the whole movie. & the extreme shots of humans getting sprayed with water? I've seen episodes of Xena: Warrior Princess that look better than this. 7. The acting is disgusting. John Travolta & Forrest Whitaker ought to be ashamed of themselves. How can they deliver lines that sound like they were written by 12 year old kids? I'm not kidding. 12 year old children. Why do the aliens call humans "man animals?" If they think of people as animals why not just call them "man?" They don't say "rat animals" or "dog animals." 8. The plot is just plain stupid. Why does John Travolta take Barry Pepper to a library for a half hour or so where he finds... the constitution??? Why? Seriously I want to know why. 9. Oh yeah that reminds me... when Barry Pepper is in the prison he draws a sketch of his girlfriend on a piece of old leather & somehow... some... how... he's such a good artist that the aliens recognize her when she's out in the wild on her horse so they can hold her hostage & get him to behave. I mean come on!To sum it up this movie is more or less a Scientology sci-fi story (sort of) written by LA dick-heads who think they are being deep when they come up with ideas like "if civilization was destroyed for 1000 years humans would think mannequins were once people who had disobeyed the gods... dude that's freaking smart!"Anyway that's only about .000001% of what's bad about this movie. I've always liked post-apocalyptic movies no matter how bad but this one is just an absolute turd no matter how you slice it. There is no way anyone could reasonably say this is not one of the worst movies ever made. It sucks. But I recommend it if you like seeing cave men flying jets (which I kind of do.)

This movie is true to L Ron Hubbard's novel. It not only conveys the book's atmosphere but also its satire. John Travolta is brilliant as Terl with his fixation on "leverage" status and rats. It's a study in the fantastic and yes it IS meant to be funny in many places. You just have to look closely to see parallels between the Psychlos and some of the sadder specimens in modern human society...The special effects are also convincing: Travolta and Whitaker really do manage to be eight foot aliens for a couple of hours!Battlefield Earth is a very fast-paced film and even though it only reached the halfway mark in the book (wait for the sequel) there's a great deal of action and data to assimilate: keep up or be left behind. An extra half hour would have left us less breathless - particularly if we haven't read the book - and we could have savoured Terl's plottings for just a little longer.Battlefield Earth may be in a similar SF genre to Soylent Green the Planet of the Apes series or THX 1138 -and probably more of a classic. It illustrates a pretty dystopian future for Earth and the galaxy so despite Johnny Goodboy's heroism it may best lie alongside that 'blacker' class of film rather than the good clean-shaven futuristic swashbuckling of Star Wars or Independence Day. Watch out for the satire follow the outrageous intrigues and be entertained.

Anybody who has ever dreamed of a decent post-apocalyptic movie this is it. I can see how so many people can dislike this movie I don't recommend it unless you are open and love SciFi. This is a cult classic or it will be. I can also see how they spent 70 million dollars the special effects are seamless and the sets are huge. This movie is about human perseverance and amazing ability to adapt. There is also a scene where rock is being blown up and there are a million particles everywhere like that lobby scene from the Matrix. Only this movie came before the Matrix. This movie has no good acting no plot almost no writing but it is very interesting and I think it triggers imagination if you have one that is.

column4: I believe it was suppose to be a comedy.
column5: My dad and I loved this movie ! John Travolta and Forest Whitaker were hilarious as the evil mean and stupid aliens! When I saw it on DVD it was the first time I had ever heard of it. The photo on the front had Travolta smiling slightly evilly. I wasn't disappointed because I thought it was a sci-fi comedy. I got it and then I had to bring it over to my dad for him to watch. I always thought John Travolta was great in comedy. I know others loved him in Pulp Fiction (and he was great in that also). I think John Travolta really did mean for his and Forest and the rest of the aliens to come across as more comedic than evil characters. They gave Barry Pepper an award for worst actor I think. Maybe because he kind of whisper/yelled out his dialogue which was suppose to inspire his comrades to fight. But soon after I saw Barry Pepper in a movie called"The Snow Walker". Barry played a lead character and I was amazed by his performance!!!! He was awesome in The Snow Walker !

When I saw the commercials for this movie a traitorous thought crept into my mind: "This can't possibly be as bad as has been said". As it happened it was worse. Now I can watch nearly any kind of film and have a good time at it but watching this felt like crawling through solidified tar with jagged pieces of glass in it. Slow plodding with the only exciting bits being worse than the boredom. I think everyone should see this once so they can appreciate other movies more.The only positive thing in all this was the hilariously huge codpieces in the aliens' suits but since Hubbard loathed psychiatrists I will not mention the word "overcompensating"...I can see how this was made to resemble Star Wars with the visuals and the main plot outline: the cosmic Rastafarian bad guy wearing all-black and having some devices implanted to make him resemble Darth. All we'd need is the good guy in white pajamas some headgear on Travolta and a bunch of irritating 'funny' aliens to bring in the younger kids.Some reference to how bad this really is is the fact that I loaned this on VHS from a friend who never throws anything away. When I had seen through to the end of the film I went to take it back to her just to be told that she didn't want it back and I was free to take it to the woods and burn it for all she cared. I complied.

This movie was terrible. The worst I've ever seen on so many different levels from basic storytelling principles writing special effects makeup acting believability & pretty much everything in it. I can't believe I've seen a few positive reviews on here. One person loved the idea that our caveman-like relatives in the future would worship everyday items from the year 2000. Of course they would but that doesn't make for a good movie. For a movie to be good you need to actually care about the characters. These cavemen are leaderless mongrels until Barry Pepper's character shows up & gives them a 30 second speech & then all is well. There is no depth to it at all. The same positive review said it had a good message about how we treat those weaker than ourselves. Again it was totally on the surface no depth whatsoever. If you want to see a futuristic movie that actually conveys some universal truths about humans watch "Children of Men." "Battlefield Earth" had about as much depth & truth as a Hannah Montana song.

I really gave this the fairest try I could despite knowing about its horrible reputation. I wasn't even in a position to be let down. I went into this film skeptical about the claims made about it by so many. Yet here I am 2/10.The best part of this film is whenever John Travolta is on screen. His overacting is the only aspect of the film I have any amount of fun with because- while I'm laughing at the film- at least it's getting something out of me.My biggest issue with this film is its pacing. I'e seen this film a few times and every time I come out of this film exhausted feeling as if I sat through a film that was 3 hours long or so. I guessed that it was probably 2 1/2 hours long only to find out that it doesn't even reach the 2 hour mark. This film progresses in such a slow way and so little happens in it. If a proper film was made from the material covered in this film it would probably be closer to 80 minutes. It's such a slog and there's no real payoff in the end.The action scenes are extremely slow-paced and boring. It almost feels like all of the action scenes are in slow motion. My memory is a little foggy but none of the action is interesting and the bland cinematography doesn't help either.The visual effects used in this film have aged badly. A lot of them now look like they were rendered on video game hardware. Of course the use of visual effects to this extent was still pretty ambitious at the time and the only contemporary of this film that really holds up at all is Star Wars Episode I but...I wish I could say more positive things but everything I could possibly ask for in a science fiction film or science fiction action film is barely present in this film and even then not executed well at all. John Travolta is the only thing I liked and that was because I love it when he overacts. I was not invested in his character and I was instead looking forward to his over-the-top line delivery and physical acting. This is a film which manages to be only 117 minutes long yet feel longer than films significantly longer than this. It's inept and that's unfortunate. My only hypothesis is that maybe the source material wasn't very strong to begin with? Who knows though...

I just can't imagine how this movie was released. It is that bad. Not bad in an Ed Wood Mystery Science sense. Just plain unwatchable.I understand the bankrolling and politics behind it but it still took some cooperation by people who had to understand that it was a turkey and an instant demerit and wouldn't want to be associated with such a mess.From story to special effects to acting it's a wretched piece. There is good bad and bad bad -- White Castle hamburgers are good bad but hospital cafeteria food is just bad bad. This movie is just plain bad bad.

Word is that the DVD will fill in some holes between the movie and the book. The book was an unparalleled page-turner that kept me up all night. The DVD will apparently contain more continuity and be smoother than the movie. Some critics really "grokked" what the sense and plot of the movie was all about its irony and satires. As for the other critics well they also didn't like Rambo or Clint Eastwood's movies (till he turned 50).I go for clever turns of plot action the occasional laugh and memorable lines. I personally think that Battlefield Earth has them all. (But too bad we didn't see more of Terl's paramour!)

OK I've read a few positive reviews on here people saying "it's not that bad" & "you only hate it because you expected it to be great" etc. Let me just say I didn't expect anything one way or the other from it. I didn't know anything about it & rented it on a whim. It is terrible. It is so bad there are few words that can describe it. To anyone who liked this movie even moderately I say this: this movie is filled with plot holes & shoddy film making to an unbelievable extent. Please think about what you are watching. This movie cost over $70000000 & it grossed $21000000. I know box office results are petty & a poor indicator of a good movie because some of the best movies ever made have been unsuccessful in their own times but this movie was unsuccessful because it just plain sucks! This is one instance when the mass movie going public is correct. It didn't make much money because it is a very poorly made movie. If you haven't seen it go watch it & actually think about what you are watching. There are a lot of terrible movies out there & many of them cost a lot of money but this movie fails on every single principle of film making. The acting the writing the directing the sfx the camera work you name it. I'm all for movies that are mindless & entertaining even stupid at times. But this movie is bad because it was pretending to actually be smart. It was a vanity project that was trying to make a point but instead just makes a mess of itself.

Filming a shoe for an hour and a half would earn a 1 out of 10 so I'll give it a 2 for that. It DID have entertainment value but...I found myself so confused at times and not just confused but completely lost struggling for long periods of time trying to make SENSE of what was actually taking place.Often during the movie I amused myself pretending it was an adventurous role playing computer game and that i was watching someone play and those cheesy dialogs unfold.Yes I can honestly say that it was very amusing to watch I laughed a lot actually and I'm glad I took the time to watch it!The movie should definitely come with a warning though something in the lines of danger of damage to the mind itself. Some of the scenes were so confusing you see so confusing... made no sense... no sense... did I mention that?But whatever some kid's shows are more confusing and definitely worse in general and you've seen them so go ahead watch the movie just for the RUSH!

column4: I only had to pay 50 cents to see this ha ha ha
column5: Because I only paid 50 cents to see this piece of garbage I will be more generous than the other unfortunates who saw this movie. I gave it a 5 based on the fact that I loved the way this movie looked. I also love the guy who played the hero and my hormones made me give it a 5 based on that. Am I a movie critic? No....Am I switchboard operator with too much time on my hands....yes. I wouldn't suggest seeing this movie unless you can see it for the low low price of 50 cents. Even then I'd suggest not wasting your time.

This is the movie you can't miss. I've always felt like I don't belong and sad and stuff. This movie makes you feel good and shows you the way. I now base the way I do my hair after the way Terl does his. The plot is very exciting and all but it's the messages about life that will keep you coming back again and again. I don't want to ruin the plot for those who haven't seen the movie yet (you'll thank me later) but this was the role that put John Travolta back on top after he almost ruined his career starring in that flop Pulp Fiction. This movie is wall to wall excitement and perfect for anyone with an open mind and an open brain. I invite anyone and everyone who doesn't agree with my review to e-mail me telling me why I'm wrong. That's what I thought.
It is not bad movie. I'm so surprised by the low rating. It doesn't deserve to be this low on the list. I really like the movie. It interesting fun and not boring at all I enjoy watching it.

This has got to be the worst movie of all time. Even Ed Wood's films are better. Taking out the plot the actors the director the screenwriter the novelist the producers the special effects and anyone else involved in conceiving this it was a great movie. WARNING: If you see this movie your IQ may be lowered to hideous averages.

column4: Wow--I found it to be totally entertaining great story!!!
column5: This was an exciting film about human efforts to survive against all odds. I particularly enjoyed the visuals in the movie including the costumes of the aliens. This movie presents to us the actual possibility of conditions man would face should earth be overrun by a more technologically advanced race. The acting was excellent by Travolta Whitaker and Pepper. Their roles must have been a real challenge given the uniqueness of the characters. I enjoyed every minute of this movie and highly recommend it to others--it is fast paced humorous and thought stimulating.

column4: Not as bad as it seemed.
column5: Ok it's not among the best movies I have seen but it's far away from the worst ones. I both read and heard some terrifying stuff about this movie before I decided to rent it on video and see it and then decide if it really was that bad. After seeing Armageddon I braced my self!As you see I had no high expectations about this move I had read the book many years ago I thought it was really great book despite it was written by L. Ron Hubbard and I imagined it would be hard to make a movie about the story. Maybe it was good that I read the book so many years ago so I lost the imaginary image I had about the characters in the book but I remember that the Psychlos was supposed to look really grotesque! But in the movie they only acted bad they didn't look repelling enough to be believable and that is pretty fundamental for the story.I was pleased to discover that the move wasn't half as bad as the earlier mentioned Armageddon and despite some over exaggerated scenes the movie was quite enjoyable and the story pretty engaging. The story was however very compressed and I can see that considering the move was 'only' about 2h long.I was expecting a B movie style special effects but even the special FX was better then I had expected. Some of the actors was not so good but what movie doesn't have it's share of them?Summary: If you like SciFi and have a couple of hours to spend I can recommend this movie.

column4: a new place in the classics
column5: This is another classical movie. (Sorry if it spoils your idea of a good movie) But it does exist and is good stuff in its way.I'don't know why but I like it!Perhaps it is the book. Could we take it seriously?It is just fun.Please enjoy it. Don't analyze it! It is not for thinking.It is like "The Return of the Living Dead" they originally made it for fun. Don't take it personal!I believe that art is appreciated in a relaxed state. Some films are more artistic than others so what?Perhaps they should put this film in the Type B quality. So what?It might be a matter of taste. I like it! (sorry buy I had to reach the 10 lines limit to get this posted)

column4: A Film That Was More Of A Battlefield When Making It
column5: Never in the history of motion pictures have I seen a film that is as bad as it is slated until now. This piece of cinematic tripe is one of the worst films I have ever seen with my own two eyes and the fact that is only at number 44 in The Internet Movie Database's 100 worst films list makes me wonder what on earth the other top 43 films are like.I have no sympathy for anyone making or related to anyone involved in this battlefield of a project. First of all the script is a right and honourable flawed with some of the most irritating insults I have ever hear and one of the most annoying and poor insult in the history of cinema on a repeatable basis. I was fed up by the number of times I heard "rat brain" from Travolta's screen-hogging character that I lost faith in listening to another line of dialogue ever again in this film with tolerance.And you thought slating the script was going to be my main argument for this appalling film. Well you will be wrong. That is only the tip of the iceberg of such rubbish! The imagery made things so bland and flat that if failed to make me understand what is going on throughout the whole film which is has not been helped in the least by some of the most shoddy slow-motion effects I have ever seen especially when it comes to seeing those long-hair humans getting hunted down by an alien is extremely dull. Even a fly landing on the TV screen would have been more entertaining to watch then that sequence and while I am still slating it for the rest of the bland sci-fi action.The effects don't do justice either as I have seen more better effects in films made 40-50 years ago then watching the attempt of some poor blue-screen work making some scenes in it almost unbelievable. Moreover if anyone finds this effects believable should seek therapy immediately for the sake of humankind! Well that's it! I am even fed up of writing a review of this film so I want to conclude as quickly this film grabbed my attention which was not that long! This film is an insult to sci-fi film-making I will never trust John Travolta as a respectable actor after a performance so poor as that and I advise anyone that really wants to watch it to view something else with effects that are more effective (The Day the Earth Stood Still anyone?) a film with better imagery (like 2001:A Space Odyssey) or has a script with sharper dialogue (may I suggest Aliens for this one for its much better insults to the aliens.) And have I mentioned that it is definitely the worst film I have ever seen? I have? Good. I shall leave you to watch this film at your own risk.

column4: Only the special effects are good
column5: Stinks on ice. Made only for the affection some had/have for the author of the book which is a terrible book.Derivative with an agenda that appeals only to a minority of opinions. Produced I suspect only because of energetic arm-twisting and outright dis-information.Fortunately the book reads quickly since no deep thinking is needed. Sitting through this film might be done on fast-scan but why bother.This was a task of love for some honoring an eccentric whose other more philosophical works are also derivative.Devotees and victims of inbreeding could enjoy this but I suspect that few of the former would find this interesting. Well die-hard Travolta fans might. This man is a sometimes superb actor and some of his efforts are on my favorites list -- NOT this one.

I consider this movie to be a hyped-up television series. These types of movies should go straight to video. Don't get me wrong the movie was enjoyable yet not at all good. I had too many unanswered questions; situations were undeveloped and left for assumptions. No part of this movie impressed me. 'Battlefield Earth'... wrong title for this movie. A good-old Star-Trek episode will do.

The combination of creative camera angles sets sound track among other elements make this movie unique. I can see how some would not be comfortable with the atmosphere created by it's director but I found it edgy. Forget the critics and their carping see it for yourself.

column4: The long lost brother of "Manos Hands of Fate"
column5: I'm a pretty huge sci-fi fan so I'll try any sci-fi movie at least once. So when I was stalking around the video store on a Friday night I thought that "Battlefield Earth" would be a good thriller to keep me awake. I mean how bad could it be?I've decided to stop renting movies.Not really but I have decided to stop assuming that all sci-fi movies have something good about them. The cover of this particular video falsely hints at a film with plenty of clever action to cover up a most-likely thin plot. Well I was right about one thing.Yes the movie does have action; in fact the last half hour of the movie is crammed with large-scale battle scenes including an eye-appealing dogfight between alien ships and harrier fighters (I'm not even going to ask what BRITISH-MADE harriers are doing in the UNITED STATES). But as so many movies have shown us before expensive special effects cannot always cover up a really truly AWFUL movie. Believe me no film to date can attest to this as much as "Battlefield Earth." The story isn't the problem; as a matter of fact L. Ron Hubbard's idea of an alien-controlled Earth in the next millennium is quite intriguing for a sci-fi audience. It's just the horrible way the film was made that makes it shall I say Mystery Science Theater material.First the movie plows right into an already underdeveloped plot giving virtually no background for the main character (an achingly bad actor with whom one finds it very hard to sympathize). Then it continues on boring its audience with unbelievable plot twists and annoying scenes transitions each one with a screen wipe. What's with that?Anyway I am essentially trying to tell those of you out there who find some of these bad movies intriguing beware. It is rarely if ever worth it.

This movie is so bad it defies description.The experience starts with the back of the movie box which extols the virtues of Battlefield Earth. These include but are not limited to "An entirely new style of science fiction film-making" "Good scene transitions" and (my personal favorite) action that will leave you "exhausted". Sadly the box said nothing about inane dialogue ineffably awful acting and a plot that has so many holes in it it could be used to strain spaghetti. In my opinion before watching this movie you must check the logic centre of your brain at the door lest it shut down permanently from the strain of trying to make sense of the fact that a highly technologically advanced alien species was still unable to discover Fort Knox.If you want a fun drinking game (and I firmly believe that generous quantities of alcohol can only improve the viewing experience) take a drink/shot every time a Psychlon says the phrase "Man-Animals" and every time you catch a glimpse of John Travolta's and Forrest Whitakker's grotesquely over-sized...uh...packages.Speaking of Forrest Whitakker the man is an Oscar winner. Did he not know what he was getting himself into? Why did he stay once he realized what was going on around him. Some of his dialogue seems like a cry for help. It's unfortunate that his career had to suffer through this movie although maybe it's just as well that he got it out of the way early. Unlike John Travolta.Improbably Travolta is worse in Battlefield Earth than he was in Broken Arrow. The man puts in the performance of a lifetime an awful performance in what he must have known was an awful movie.I have run out of words. If you really must watch this movie watch it with a group of people with whom you can mercilessly tear it to shreds. At least you'll get some enjoyment out of it that way. I still have not mentioned the forgettable score bad editing and terrible cinematography which seems to live in mortal fear of any shots that occur at a completely vertical angle. Now I have. Don't say I didn't warn you.

column4: read the book(s) before you watch this one...
column5: Have you read L. Ron Hubbard's 'Battlefield Earth'? Do even know who this man was? Ever heard about the Church Of Scientology? Well Hubbard was the man who created that church. I suggest you read the book and then watch the movie...Now about this film. It's not bad. I loved the book and I loved the movie. The only thing that bothered me was that the movie was too short. Over 1500 pages of a great sci-fi novel in a 117 minute-movie. All other - the acting cam work effects R. Christian vision of the novel - was great.I have to admit that I like b-class sci-fi movies but knowing the backgrounds of this film one thing is sure - it's not worth 2 out of 10. I'll give it a fair 8.And to all of you out there. Read the book before you vote!

column4: Review written by author actress Vivian Schilling.
column5: I received this review from Vivian Schilling and wanted to pass it along to readers. `Battlefield Earth' is a Sci/Fi film like no other. From the opening you're sucked into a fantastical world unto itself with dark images of giants pitted against the last survivors of the human race. Reminiscent of `Planet of the Apes' with man -- stripped of technology and thrown back to his roots -- `Battlefield Earth' is an epic adventure the whole family will enjoy. Not your run-of-the-mill science fiction film it delves into man's age old quest for knowledge and the delicate balance of technology versus nature. If you liked the novel you'll love the movie with its visually stunning and unique approach to the material. It takes Hubbard's characters and colors them with the 21st century in sleek costume designs and state-of-the-art make-up effects. John Travolta as the Psychlo villain looms before us employing humor in his evil antics so effectively it will make your skin crawl. Barry Pepper proves to be an engaging and likable hero leading the enslaved humans in a winner-take-all battle for the planet. `Battlefield Earth' is a great escape from the summer heat!Vivian Schilling Author Actress and Screenwriter

column4: Did they even bother to READ the book?
column5: I have been Robbed... Battlefield Earth is one of the very few books that I faithfully read every year. It's one book that could keep you glued to your chair page after page after page. The movie does not only take liberties with the plot and subplots but totally invents new characters and devices. Changes the whole meaning of the story. I feel SICK sick at the thought that so many people will see this crap.. and think that it could be based upon the book. I waited for twenty-five years for the Movie. Now I hope to live long enough for a remake.. Save Your Money. READ THE BOOK...

I didn't find the film to be as bad as I expected but this may simply be because I had lowered my expectations so much as a result of the bad reviews that anything would be an improvement.I felt that the film made a promising start indicating an interesting although not original plot about a defeated humanity fighting back against alien invaders. It then seemed to lose its way.The Psychlos look like derivatives of the klingons and John Travolta seems to overact. The manner in which the humans gain knowledge the utter stupidity of the Psychlos in giving them that knowledge and the amazing way in which ancient aircraft were still airworthy (among other things) raises questions about the film.Having said all of this I repeat that I didn't find it quiet as bad as I was led to expect. I still however regard it as one of the misses of the year.

Battlefield Earth was probably one of the worst sci-fi movies I've ever seen in my life. After the first hour of the film people in the cinema walked out in disgust that they wasted their $10.50 to see this garbage. I admit the special effects were one of the best effects I've seen in a long time but what so good about the special effects if there's no storyline to back it up? Take "Star Trek" "Star Wars" and "Independence Day" and you get "Battlefield Earth" nothings original. My advice to you people out there is save your hard earned money and go see "Gladiator." If you want to see a classic then watch "Independence Day" and any of the "Star Wars" sequels. oh did I forget to mention that the acting was even worse than the movie? Come on "John" you can do better than that!

...this has to be THE number one worst movie ever. I mean they had a budget they had a few actors they had a funny neo-religious sect... I was expecting at least a good laugh but I wouldn't even recommend this crap to ... Ron Hubbard.

column4: Not as bad as I heard but I still walked out.
column5: Poor John Travolta his directing ability will be listed with names like Ed Wood and William Shatner. I really wanted to like this movie hoping against hope that the critics were wrong. Turns out they weren't that far off. As I feared this movie is more disappointing than "The Postman". After seeing this I have come to two possible conclusions:1) John Travolta talented actor he may be cannot direct worth a dime.2) L. Ron Hubbards' brilliant science fiction writing cannot be simply translated into another "Independence Day".If Travolta had bothered to throw in a scene or two of how Johnny and his band managed to get those harrier jets working electricity restored etc. I would have sat through it. I also find it hard to believe that some uneducated tribe members can learn to fly harrier jets better than air force pilots in a week. If it was Travolta's intent to dumb down the translation from book to film he overdid it. Travolta manages to insult his audience by leaving gaping holes in logic and storyline laughable scripts and dialogue. Don't worry about any subliminal Scientology messages the film isn't that sophisticated. If you read the book don't see the movie. Save yourself the disappointment and retain the good memories you have of the book.

If you've read the book you'll be extremely disappointed in this movie If you havent read the book not only will you be disappointed but you'll be confused as well. Basic plot lines from the book were completely skipped over in order to speed through the movie in doing so they've made it so confusing to follow that without reading the book you may miss have the movie. They've left it wide open for a sequel that hopefully wont be done.

I enjoy a lot of movies I generally see something worthwhile in most films I watch through to the end. But there are some films I switch off prior to ending (like the recent Tom Hanks film The Ladykillers) and for the most part I cannot be bothered even rating those films. I quite liked the book Battlefield Earth. So I thought I'd give this film another chance (I fell asleep during the first attempt) but it really is a waste of time. Watch Hudson Hawk instead - that at least does not take itself seriously. Even with a recent re-read of the book I found it difficult to follow the story. Battlefield Earth is a confused incoherent movie that deserves to be given a wide-berth.

column4: Fun Flick fast paced gotta love those psychlos!
column5: I read a number of the other reviews here and thought are these guys for real!?! Maybe I wandered into "Frustrated film critics school" whatever! Its a science fiction film and no doubt will become a cult classic. Terl and Ker are "Moe and Shemp" I was wondering what happened to "Larry." (I loved them they were worth the price of admission alone.)So down to the film. I read Battlefield Earth when it came out. I felt that Travolta and crew were wise to break the book into two parts and cut the story at the correct point.The book itself runs as the movie does. Lots of action the movie is basically one long action sequence. The movie presents Hubbard's satircal humor well and if you have not read B'Earth (as most of those commenting here) and are into fiiillmmm (as it seems most commenting here are) then you will be too busy trying to figure out "why the film angle?" or looking for "subliminals" that some idiot claimed were in the movie. So what is the movie? A huge fun rollercoaster ride! Loud explosive alien idiocy killer effects and of course...good triumphs over evil!Sci-Fi as it should be!

column4: Most one-liners have a better story then this movie
column5: The acting in this movie is not bad neither are the special effects or the camera work. The story on the other hand is one of the worst I have ever seen. I myself am a fan of sci-fi movies and books and although not every sci-fi writer is known here I have never seen a book for L Ron Hubbard in the book stores in the sci-fi department. I wonder why? Well after seeing the movie you will know why. This movie could be seen as the perfect example of how to use good actors and good special effects and end up with one of the worst movies ever. A must see if you are in to that kind of movies.

This movie never should have been made. Travolta has tarnished his image as a box office big hitter with this dud. The movie doesn't make sense. The aliens come to earth and wipe us out in a matter of days and now a band of cavemen who can barely speak learn how to fly harrier jets in 9 hours and take back the earth and blow up the aliens home planet. The story (if you can call it one) takes you nowhere and it seems like there are scenes missing from the story. Go see Gladiator for a second or third time instead of seeing this movie

I am a huge sci-fi fan and there are times that I love to watch really bad sci-fi movies and TV shows but Battlefield Earth goes far far beyond just being bad. This movie is so unwatchable it gives bad movies a really really bad name. Yes the special effect are great but the story and the dialoge and just about everything else about it is well how do I say this: horrid a waste of film about as much fun as a root-canal without novicane. While watching this excrement I think that one can actually hear their brain cells dying. This movie makes Plan 9 From Outer Space look like Hamlet. Truly the absolute worst of the worst. (and I'm a sci-fi fan)

No words can describe how terrible this movie was. The effects were poor the acting was bad the story was terrible and the physics were horrific. There were scenes stolen directly out of Braveheart and the Matrix. Under no circumstances should anyone ever be forced to see this movie. John Travolta put his heart and soul into this film and it is nothing more than a joke. Very very sad.

This is the one and only movie I've ever seen that I would say is "so bad it's good". Usually the novelty of these movies wear off really fast . This movie was so stupid that i couldn't help but be entertained by it

column4: Read the book skip the movie
column5: OK so I bought the book at Barnes & Noble for a buck because well it was a buck. I did a little online research about it and found that a lot of people liked the book and pretty much everyone hated the movie so I decided to go into the reading of the book with an open mind.I'm so glad I did! The book is awesome! It's a damn good read and I would and have recommended to my friends. So then I decided today that maybe the movie isn't as bad as everyone says especially for someone who's read the book... uh wrong. The movie strays so far off from the book that it's at times unrecognizable as the same story. The scenes look like they were set up by a high school student that is studying to be in film and the acting is well atrocious.My advice is read the book and enjoy. Don't waste your time on the movie.

What I can't figure out is how such an amazing Si-if book could be so badly turned into a screen play. This book needed the Peet Jackson treatment but instead got mutated into some weird Frankenstein of a re-write. L.Ron Hubbard would roll in his grave if he was forced to watch his masterpiece be mutilated in such a poor fashion. The screen writer (Corey Mandell) and ultimately John Travolta who produced the film departed from the script so often that any fan of the original book is bound to be disgusted.Often times in screen play adaptation it is necessary to change portions of the original book to better suit the film going audience. However in this case they might as well have renamed the film and not credited the original author. There are so many bad choices in the form of cuts and additions that the film in no way resembles the original piece which inspired it. In fact if Hubbard was alive today I would wager he would disassociate himself from the film work entirely.I personally loved the book and disagree with screen writer Corey Mandell who stated that the original book was "clunky and the dialog awkward." In fact his adaptation coupled by the worst direction of any big budget Si-Fi movie ever is the only "clunky" thing in the room.For example The idea of Phyclos looking exactly like humans on stilts in 70's lift shoes is a total embarrassment to all costume designers everywhere. In fact the awful costuming dismal set design and off kilter cinematography totally killed any real fear that Hubbard intended to create when he wrote the world of Phyclos into existence. In addition the use of 1000 year old Earth tech to overcome the Pyclo's is ridiculously unbelievable. In what reality would 1000 year old fighter jets fire up and destroy a Psyclo compound? Finally the movie starts with green letters flashing across the screen. They say"Man is an endangered species". The weird thing is that the idea never comes up again. In the book Hubbard dances on that string as a steady dis-tonic note of fear throughout the story line. Mandell totally fails the audience by not keeping the essence of that tension in the film.Truth be told. The only way to really recreate Hubbard's work on the big screen would be by breaking it up into 3 full length movies. Conveniently Hubbard writes the book in 3 distinct sections. He starts with a fractured picture of humanity hanging by a thread. Moves into a section where a thousand years of lost knowledge is recovered and fragmented society is reconnected. Then finishes with a twist when Humanity crushes Phyclo but then has to fight to stay afloat in galaxy filled with alien races out to fill the void left by the fall of Phyclo. It all ends with a huge political grand finally where Earth emerges as a universal leader and humanity is saved.In truth one real criticism of the book is that it starts out a touch slow. But after chapter 1 goes into high gear for 1000 amazing pages. However the first chapter info is very important to the plot. A creative way to have handled that issue would have been to filter that info into the first and second movie via flash backs. In that way the movie could have started off at a strong pace that would grab a film audiences attention but still kept the integrity of the story. Any way you slice it up there is no possibility of packing an Epic novel like Battlefield Earth into a 120 minute quick flick.To boil it all down to the lowest common denominator. The only thing Epic about this movie is how epically it fails all film goers. Whether you are a fan of the book or not this film was so badly made it fails us all. I highly recommend the book if you are a Si-Fi reader. You will love it! For years it has wowed new and old readers alike. If all you have seen regarding Battlefield Earth is this film you are missing out. If you haven't yet seen the film skip it and go to the source. You will be happy you did.

column4: I've no idea how many times I have read the book
column5: I've no idea how many times I've read the book that this movie is supposed to be based on. But I've read it enough times to be rather familiar with it. As such I was *very* disappointed with the movie. Sure it had some of the same characters (but only some - where was Brown Limper? I was quite looking forward to see who got picked for that part) it was set in about the right area and the bare basic story was about right (but only the absolute basics - humans trying to retake their world from aliens. Practically *all* of the subplots from the book were missing).However right at the very beginning the movie starts deviating from the book. And it goes downhill from there. Most of the happenings in the movie bore absolutely *no* resemblance to *anything* in the book. How Terl captured Johnny the vehicles used where all the other "man-animals" came from the layout of the company complex the size of the Psychlos the relation between Terl and Ker how Johnny got the bomb to Psychlo where the humans got the gold - none of these happenings in the movie bore any resemblance to the book. They weren't even close.When viewed as just a movie it wasn't too bad. I'd say about a 7 out of 10. The FX were pretty good and (as much as I hate to admit this) Travolta did quite a good job as Terl. But when viewed as a movie adaptation of the book it was a miserable flop - 2 out of 10. The only thing saving it from a 1 was again the FX and Travolta's portrayal of Terl. This was such a bad adaptation it was almost unrecognizable as such.

I'm not one to talk about things like continuity or editing or plot holes. After all... I live off of the hi-gloss Jerry Bruckheimer Hollywood varnished roller coaster movies as much as any true MOVIEgoer but really... I could've had a V8 This was SOOOO bad! I was AMAZED at how bad this movie was. I literally looked at my girlfriend and almost apologized for having paid full price for it.I WANT MY MONEY BACK.

Although the movie did not follow the book as it could have it still had some great Sci-Fi effects. That is what should be discussed regarding this movie. Any true Sci-Fi fan would love the sets costumes and special effects. And - any true Sci-Fi fan would know that the book is one of the best in its genre!

column4: A rating of 1 is too high.
column5: This is clearly the worst film ever put in a can. It had no chance from the start. When you have an idiot for the original writer and then you have a screenwriter that hasn't produced a screenplay for nineteen years bad things are bound to happen.
