column4: It's bad but it's also good fun
column5: First of all this is an indie film. This was a project of Travolta which all the studios rejected and he had to fund it himself. Obviously the movie suffers greatly from the lack of good actors and directing. The lack of money is evident. But this movie is great fun and very comical. I was laughing hard at some scenes not that they were good but that they were so obviously bad and I know everyone in the movie knew that it was bad. I mean John Travolta and Forest Whitaker are brilliant actors and they knew that this is gonna be bad so they just had fun. This was done in 2000 so it's morally old but so are other movies. If you take it as a joke you will enjoy how bad it is. I mean we are always watching stuff like this in YouTube and not complaining.On a separate note I would like to add that this movie is WAY WAY WAY better than stuff like Charlie's Angels 2019 Birds of Prey and other propaganda nonsense movies which are not even funny but have huge budgets trying to push some agenda on us. So enjoy this indie movie and remember to not take is seriously. There are much worse movies out there in 2020.

There is a line where a film is so bad that it actually becomes good and I thought BE was going to be one of those films.For years I heard and read that this film was so bad that it was comical and I was looking forward to that.Sadly it did not turn out that way. This movie was actually OK. Not great by any means but really not that bad.I had expected super cheesy effects terrible acting a story line that made no sense but it didn't have it. In fact the only really cheesy part of it was the menu on the DVD.I think the reason people love to hate this film is it's obvious connection to Scientology. I'm no big fan of Scientology but people seem to take great pleasure in bashing them and this film is a perfect outlet for that. But all in all Starship Troopers was much worse in a way that made it good.Does that make sense? I don't think I have ever been so let down by expecting something to be so bad.

column4: Soooooo Terribly Bad - Not Worth Watching!!!
column5: This has to be the worst example of novel-to-movie I have ever seen. For those who have not read the book it might have only been a terrible experience to endure but for those such as myself who have read the L. Ron Hubbard book it's totally ridiculous. The only thing about this movie that resembles the book is the title itself. To lower the work of L. Ron Hubbard to such a low level is a shame. I was hoping for so much from this movie and I received nothing. I had to force myself to watch it just in hopes of seeing something that resembled what I read. Please if you know someone who might might be thinking of renting the video do them a huge favor and talk them out of it.

In my perfect world there would be ratings for people who rate movies. I would very much like to be able to quickly access like-minded peoples' opinions of a movie that I am interested in watching. Is there an app for this already? Please direct me to it if there is so that I don't have to search thru this mindless bunch of people who give numerous 1 star reviews. A clue; This is a 10 star rating system which is great if used properly. For example you look and see a movie rated 7 or 8 or 9; all those #'s give you different nuanced subtle feeling. If you get tired looking for a great movie you start looking for anything over 5 and might settle even on a 5 if it was up your alley or had a favorite actor or two. No way are you going to watch a 4 or lower unless it's a cult classic or a friend says you "gotta see it" for some crazy scene or theme. So if you don't like a movie give it a 3 or a 4 or even a 5 if you have a bit of an insight that someone with different tastes might like it. But to give a movie a 1 star@"?# Reserve a 1 star the way that you should reserve a 10 star. Use it once or twice in your life and let it have an impact for yourself and the rest of us.

column4: Finally proof of Travolta's missing acting skills
column5: I've said for years that Travolta is a terrible actor. The problem has always been that a few good directors have made decent movies despite him not because of him. These 'red herring' movies have put reasonable doubt into the minds of the jury of public opinion.However this movie leaves no doubt about his abilities. With him in charge(producer) and as the lead there is no one to blame for this travesty but Travolta. Even though I was sure that 'Broken Arrow' had already settled that argument.Anyway. This movie has no legs to stand on. L. Ron Hubbard was a crackpot with barely passable writing skills. So your screenwriters had nothing to work with. Then you have Travolta basically running the whole thing. Even choosing the director and basically directing him (or so the stories go) since he didn't want his beloved cult leader's story messed up.The plot is MIA the acting horrible the cinematography so-so the FX average or less with a scene or two that are exceptions.Even though I usually enjoy a "good bad" movie I can't think of anyone that deserves to be made to watch this crap.Save your money and rent 'The Day the Earth Stood Still' instead.Note: I've tried hard to follow comment guidelines (see "Profanity obscenities or spiteful remarks." from the "What not to include" section) but this movie requires extraordinary measures.

column4: A truly beautiful and unique film
column5: Before the movie starts an horrific battle takes place that in minutes leaves Earth destroyed and mankind enslaved! The reason that it is not in the movie is because it's childs play compared to what follows. The charismatic villan Terl the Terrible is the real gold mine. With ferocity so far unparelled in the movie world Terl learns how to fire a gun hunt for gold like a ferocious lion and use his master wit to persuade a foolish rebelling earthling and his companions to help him. Between these truly elaborate and well formed scenes a decent plot developes. It's understandable that Terl would let the truly unique and well thought-out character of Jonnie the Earthling know all of his secrets. I can even see how it would be necessary for Jonnie to know all about Terl in order to hunt Gold for him. How could Terl know that Jonnie would manipulate the system and teach his friends all about the truly horrific aliens. Even if Terl found out about this betrayal how could he know that the earthlings would start a small rebellion that would later crush and overthrow the alien conquerers. In a truly magnificent and original final battle scene hundreds are killed but the earthlings come out on top to retake their home planet Earth. I can tell you now that I left the theatre feeling refreshed and exhilarated. I'm crossing my fingers for an even more fantastic sequal.

column4: A great big dose of fun
column5: I have to admit two things right from the start. I love going to the movies and I love Travolta. I'm sure glad then that I didn't read the host critic's review before going to Battlefied Earth.My take on the movie diverges greatly from the host critic's.I thought it was great fun...a perfect start to the summer movie season.Travolta was fabulous as a giant ever-scheming alien with a devilish laugh worthy of Vincent Price. His will be remembered as one of the great characters of all time in the Sci-Fi genre.The interplay between Terl played by Travolta and his "trustworthy" sidekick Ker played by Forest Whittaker was alone worth the price of admission.Of course you'd expect great special effects and sets. You won't be disappointed! They were amazing.If you want to take your family for a great big dose of good clean movie making fun go see Battlefield Earth.

I was interested in seeing this film because I saw Ron Hubbard's name (the same person who founded Scientology of the Tom Cruise fame). The story is very interesting  the world has been taken over by a very humanoid alien life form that is exploiting the earth for its minerals. Most humans are enslaved and those that are not have degenerated to a low level of technology. In spite of a significant difference in technology the humans revolt and incredibly win. But given this interesting story line this is an incredibly idiotic film. These aliens rule the universe but are incredibly stupid in how they relate to each other. In spite of much evidence to the contrary they believe that humans cannot think. They are so obviously based on the Klingons that the story borders on plagiarism. Some of the special effects were very nice (as when they aliens teach Johnny Tyler their language). For all the hardships humans face all of them appear well fed well groomed have great teeth and look great in general. The movie is lost in execution  a nice opportunity lost.

As a film industry professional and a life-long fan of sci-fi films I anxiously awaited the release of the movie BATTLEFIELD EARTH based on the novel by L. Ron Hubbard (one of the best "futuristic" books ever). I knew it would be a huge task to adapt this work to film because it's a huge far-reaching piece of writing.The makers of the film have followed a certain path through the story which gave me: immense visual excitement (the explosion of the evil planet is remarkable) tremendous acting (check out John Travolta's take on a true villain--filled with charm and seductive appeal while at the same time being totally threatening; see Barry Pepper's depiction of an action-oriented hero); see Forest Whitaker's portrayal of an underling who finally rises up in protest over his boss' mistreatment); thematic importance (an individual actually can take matters into his own hands and make them right).BE also has a wonderful balance of humor adventure action and jeopardy which kept me rapt and at the edge of my seat the whole time.A most refreshing look at the future! Destined to be a classic of the genre.--Eric Sherman Author/DIRECTING THE FILM

I've read the book twice. The book is a great and detailed look at what could happen here but I could not envision how the movie could be made (maybe that's why I'm not a film maker). So I was pleasantly surprised to see over-the-top aliens who were arrogant and brutal to the point of being funny which I believe was deliberately done to temper the bleak setting. They were very much in character as the indifferent squanderers of planets as were the natives - struggling ignorant and nearly beyond hope. The combination preserved the darkness of the subject matter. I was impressed.The visuals are great - the darkness the wilderness and the remains of the planet's infrastructure. I also enjoyed how Earth's history is interpreted by these future characters. It is above all a non-stop action movie. I think it is a great sci-fi flick and has elements that will make it a classic a la Rocky Horror Picture Show.

column4: Nowhere Near As Bad As I Expected

I couldn't find this movie anywhere until last week when I found it in the one-dollar bin at the video store the bin where bad movies go to die. I went home and started watching it. I'd read the reviews heard what my friends had said about it so I was expecting this to be bad. About half an hour in I still hadn't found something I hated very much. By the end I realized that I had enjoyed Battlefield Earth. Yes the movie has its flaws and Jesus there are too many to list but there are some positive things to say. -John Travolta'a performance as Terl is delightfully hammy and over the top. -The premise is intriguing. -The views of the post-invasion Earth (wrecked skylines of Denver Washington) are great. -And my reason for it is that it's just... cheesy. It doesn't feel like the worst movie ever made it feels like a bad episode of Star Trek and a bad episode of Stargate Atlantis had a love child and it grew up with William Shatner and Jim Carey. It's bad I'll never say it's good but I will watch it again. This movie is the ultimate guilty pleasure.

column4: You've read the reviews now get the advice!
column5: Viewer reviews have been consistently negative for this film not without reason. I was afraid it was going to be bad and calling this movie bad is too high praise. I agree with most of the other reviewers except I did like Forrest Whittaker even if he didn't fit the description or characterization in the book. I just finished re-reading the book last week. The book was about 20% action 80% plot. The screenwriters pulled about 10% (of the 20%) and shot action sequences. They forgot to add any of the plot to it.This movie can be compared to StarShip Troopers in that 10% of the book was used to make the movie and the rest was left out.Bottom line. The book costs less than if you see this movie in the evening. Skip the movie read the book. You'll get a lot more entertainment and thought provoking ideas for your money. Don't quit half-way through when it seems like the book is over. There are lots more goodies to come.

Follow that with a sandpaper massage and bathing in a tub full of lemonade and you will be approaching the sensation of watching Battlefield Earth. There is no discernible reason for the (over)use of color filters except perhaps to distract from John Travolta's complete lack of talent. Possibly the worst offence (from a technical standpoint that is) has to be the Dutch Angle -- normally used sparingly to "throw off" the viewer's perspective to create feelings of unease and/or discomfort but in Battlefield Earth is literally the only shot used. This film is the cinematic equivalent to having your genitals mangled by rabid weasels with dull teeth while laying in a Taco Bell dumpster in July. I highly recommend it.

column4: Not as bad as others would have you believe
column5: Let's get it out of the way and say it: Battlefield Earth is awful. Had it never been made the money that was used to produce it could have been used to make several better smaller-budget movies or perhaps the money could have fed children in refugee camps somewhere. But that's neither here nor there since B:E was made and it's here forever.So like the many unfortunate youths that have uncles with boundary issues we need to come to terms with what just happened to us. Battlefield: Earth is bad. It's horrible. It's an affront to all that is righteous and beautiful in this world. And it's also extremely entertaining if you view it correctly. Here are my suggestions:1) Get drunk while watching. Take a drink every time somebody says "Terl" or "gold" or something like that.2) Invite your friends over for a bad movie night and rip on it as much as you can. Nobody cares if you talk over an important plot development because let's face it there are no important plot developments.3) Watch it in a language you don't understand. Seriously I caught in on Univision one time and I found that the Spanish dub was extremely enjoyable. It was the first time I liked watching the movie and since then I have gotten more and more enjoyment with each subsequent viewing.Watching this movie is akin to drinking what you think is tea only to find that it's soda. Your brain doesn't recognize the soda flavor and for a moment you are convinced that you've consumed a poisonous batch of tea. When you first watch this movie you're expecting something wonderful but once that bad taste wears off you're left with a beautiful experience. It's bad but it's not that bad.

column4: A highly entertaining piece of sci-fi cinema!
column5: Just before the opening of John Travolta's Battlefield Earth (based on the book of the same title authored by L. Ron Hubbard) I ran across something I found very interesting. I read a review in Entertainment Weekly magazine which attacked the film in a way I had never seen done with any other film before it. Now it is a very well known fact that John Travolta is an outspoken practitioner of Scientology and that L. Ron Hubbard is that religion's founder. What I found unusual was the amount of concern dedicated to both figures. Surprisingly the entire first page of the review was dedicated to only a catty criticism of John Travolta's hair and makeup. The writer of the article Owen Gleiberman also stated that "it may take a blind zealot to believe that L. Ron Hubbard is an inspired science-fiction writer."After researching the possible truth of this statement I discovered that L. Ron Hubbard is actually one of the top sci-fi writers of all time by sales volume alone and is also widely regarded as a master of his craft by people such as the legendary Robert Heinlein himself who said of Hubbard's Final Blackout "as perfect a piece of science fiction as has ever been written!" and called Battlefield Earth "a terrific story!" It makes me wonder whether Gleiberman has ever even read any of Hubbard's work.In his article he mentions Hubbard nearly twice as often as the film's lead Barry Pepper. I've never seen an author get that much attention for a film. I therefore had the sneaking suspicion that Mr. Gleiberman may have some sort of personal grudge with either Hubbard himself or Scientology at large. In any case the curiosity of all this was such that I just had to see the film. I did end up seeing the film and I would swear I was watching an entirely different movie than the one Mr. Gleiberman commented upon. The experience was so startling it inspired me to write a review of my own.Lacking Gleiberman's religious fervor and interest in cosmetology I decided simply to stick with the basics: writing directing acting and production value. While a film can rarely live up to the book that spawned it I thought the screenplay beautifully communicated the themes which made Battlefield Earth a best-seller: the resilience of the human spirit the power of truth over deception and the triumph of knowledge over might. Two-time Academy Award-winner Roger Christian the film's director and protg of George Lucas proudly displays the hallmark qualities of his mentor. Expertly capturing the themes of the story while simultaneously allowing the talent on his set to shine unhindered each in their own unique way Christian leaves us both curious and enthralled. He paints a grimly contrasting picture of both the oppressed populations of Earth and our affluent alien captors one culture dead of technology the other dead of spirit one pulsating with the will to be free the other long ago resigned to live as slaves. Travolta (the film's villain Terl) performs with the same brilliance which has come to be expected by most movie-goers from a long and successful history of cinematic bad-boys. Like many of his other films I couldn't decide whether I loved to hate him or whether I hated the fact that I loved him. In either case he was as thrilling to watch as his creepy eyes were disturbing. Both Barry Pepper (Johnny the film's hero) and Forrest Whitaker (Terl's devious sidekick) brought with them the same honesty and realism that made them famous for their roles in Saving Private Ryan and Good Morning Vietnam respectively. Pepper definitely lives up to the larger than life reputation of Hubbard's Battlefield Earth hero Johnny Goodboy Tyler. Expect to see Pepper's already impressive career flourish grandly in the years to come. As far as the film's overall production value all I can say is that apparently when a film has one man in charge of production design creature design and costume design (in this case the supremely competent Patrick Tatopoulos of Independence Day) you get an artistic continuity unmatched by almost any sci-fi film ever made. An excellent call on the part of the film's producers Elie Samaha Johnathan D. Krane and John Travolta. In addition to the film's superb look (credit to Lucasfilm alumnus cinematographer Giles Nuttgen) the Academy Award-graced special effects team on this one definitely put in their overtime. Gripping action sequences terrific spacecraft realism and wonderfully subtle alien enhancements make Battlefield Earth one of the best films of the summer lineup. No doubt Battlefield Earth will be remembered as a highly entertaining sci-fi action thriller and anticipation of its sequel is already bubbling wildly both in the Hollywood community itself and in sci-fi and Hollywood fandom alike. Like the best-selling sci-fi novel which inspired it Battlefield Earth is truly a work not to be missed. As an end note I loved Travolta's hair and makeup. They make him look like exactly what he plays a deliciously evil intergalactic bad-ass! Go John.

Being an engineer and wanting everything to make since I don't normally like movies that have such plot errors (as everyone has pointed out here). My wife is always yelling at me "IT JUST A MOVIE" (as I point out plot errors). Also I do enjoy science fiction movies (I robot Matrix etc) TV shows (Star Trek (all of them) etc) and Books (Orson Scott Card mainly). So with all these complaints I must have missed something. When I watched this movie I was interested in it the entire way threw. So I must have been in one of those moods where I suspended logic. I guess I need to see it again so I can see what everyone is complaining about.

This film is NOT as horrible as everyone has labelled it so. I still can't understand what is so wrong. My friend Sean mentioned to me the "sloppiness" of some of the scenes and how "wipes" were used in every transition. These are problems?This is a movie about aliens *HELLO* anyone using they're brains? Yes of course there were less believable sequences as in the USA flight simulators and how quickly the human characters were to learn. With this in mind you have to remember one detail. Think for a moment; there is NO I repeat NO reality check needed here. This is a science fiction film. And as far as the acting goes I thought it was great. Maybe I am the only person to have enjoyed the alleged "worse movie of the year" and maybe; everyones opinion is inflated based on critics reviews.I thought it was brilliant how the ruthless aliens pumped all of they're own knowledge into a human. They were so indulged in they're own superiority they didn't even consider the possibility of a measly little human accomplishing an uprising. The acting was great above average at the least. The directing was perfect shots were lit well and original angles for action sequences and "close up" shots.As another plus the musical score was perfectly in tune with the action and allowed me that "alien world" feel to enjoy as I watched the story unfold.So as everybody cold shoulders this piece of originality I pity the man who has the same opinion as everyone else. This movie reminded me of "Planet of the Apes" with primitive characters that learn of the past and shape the future. This film had my attention glued to the monitor for the entire production. I respect that everyone has the right to they're own opinion it just amazes me how everyone can "agree" against it. -------Violent G

For the respect I hold for anything science fiction/fantasy I couldn't bring my self to give this movie a 1 of 10. Any movie or films that attempts to portray a new world and forge in new directions in such a conservative era has my respect. So I've respectfully given it a 2 of 10.On the flip side...oie I had to restrain myself from walking out of the theatre. Given that I wasn't the one that drove to the theatre the alternative for me was waiting outside in the cold. Once I stopped attempting to take the movie seriously and hoping that it would pick up at some point I felt a lot better. Personally I don't feel that the director meant for the audience to fall out of their seat laughing when the band of good-guys show up near the end of the movie in their Harriers.I have to say that I'm a bit insulted that the movie suggested such an over-the-top arrogant race such as the Psychlos were able to take over earth. Especially since a handful ragtag cavemen were able to overthrow their whole settlement.I couldn't find myself caring too much for the 'hero' of this movie either. Motivation that comes from where; his horse getting shot? The hero himself couldn't be more of a stereotype; never making a mistake and having seemingly endless reserves of charisma to command his followers.John Travolta I cared more about what happened to him than the hero. Travolta is a good actor and will portray any role that he is given well; and that isn't to say that he did a smash job of acting in this film.I don't recommend this film. I haven't read the book but from the other comments I've read from the people that have read the book it is worlds above the movie.

Battlefield Earth is a quasi documentary on how big corporations run their business. the internal politics the power struggle and of course the working doe. It also shows a fight for "freedom" which could also be a worker takeover (i.e. Delta airlines). Perhaps it was too witty for the audience OR not understandable to those outside of politics and/or large business standards. However I must agree that the ending was too much. Uneducated baboons learning to fly sophisticated fighter planes in three days??? Not really. Finally the end with the gold and Ker can be seen as symbolic to today's constant pursuit of wealth (although it was not intended to be so). The bottom line is that I really enjoyed this movie.. no matter what it's IMDb ranking may be.

I had a good time watching Battlefield Earth. Travolta did his usual excellent job as the absolutely wicked Terl. Travolta's ability to continuously win audiences as good guy or bad is a salute to his acting skills and his popular appeal. I had read L. Ron Hubbard's bestseller some years back and was impressed by the movie's close adherence to the book though I think the rich detail of Hubbard's book was the better of the two. The great special effects action and the tribute to the indomitable spirit of Man gave this flick a Rocky/Star Wars feel that I found briskly entertaining. This was good fast fun.

Don't be fooled! Don't waste your money! The book was simply awful and the movie (which I got a free pass for otherwise I would NEVER have gone - yes the book is that bad) actually makes it worse. At least with a book you can skim over the really tedious parts. Interesting dialogue? Plot? Characterization? Weren't in the book so I guess it was too much to ask for any of them to be in the movie. The special effects were well done but you could just as easily see ID4 Godzilla The Matrix hell go back a few years and add Aliens T2 etc if all you want are pretty pictures and actually be able to stomach (if not enjoy) the story. That simply isn't possible here. 1 out of 10.

Reviewers are already calling this movie the "Plan 9 from Outer Space" of the year 2000. That's a bit overstated; "Battlefield Earth" is worse than you ought to expect from an $80-million movie but not as bad as many of the media reviews have said. It's more like "Dune" than "Plan 9": not REALLY bad and not terribly good either just proof that some decent talent cool special effects and a few creative ideas can't save a poor script."Battlefield Earth" is based on the 1982 novel of that name by L. Ron Hubbard. The year is 3000. Earth has been overrun by the Psychlos a cruel opportunistic race of giant aliens that mine entire planets of their precious metals. A thousand years earlier (that'd be around now) the Psychlos routed the entire human race in only nine minutes. What is left of humanity now cowers in caves in the mountains where the Psychlos can't go because the radiation levels are too high (radioactivity ignites the gas they breathe). Unfortunately the radiation is slowly making the humans extinct as well. Enter Jonnie Goodboy Tyler (Barry Pepper the Bible-quoting sniper from "Saving Private Ryan") a young human who is trying to find a better way of life for his tribe. While exploring the ruins of the city of Denver he is captured by the Psychlos and pressed by their corrupt security chief Terl (John Travolta) into mining a secret vein of gold. He takes the opportunity to motivate the remainder of the Psychlos' slaves into revolting against the aliens.This ought to be an OK premise for a space opera right? Unfortunately in this script illogic carries the day. Although it is supposedly illegal to teach non-Psychlos how to mine you never see a Psychlo so much as pick up a shovel. The humans do the mining and the Psychlos are more like taskmasters (something like the Egyptians in Exodus). When Jonnie proves to be aggressive untrainable and rebellious he is marked for termination but instead Terl hooks him up to a teaching machine and gives him the knowledge he needs to stage an effective revolt. Although Terl gives Jonnie two weeks to mine the vein appparently the Psychlos were too dim to raid Fort Knox so the humans simply take that gold and spend their two weeks hunting for weapons. Fort Hood has been a ruin for a millennium but luckily the Harrier jets stored there are in working order and still full of fuel; what's more the fort still has electricity to run the Harrier simulator so that the cavemen can become Top Gunners in a week. (Heck someone even left the light on in the simulator and after 1000 years it hasn't burnt out yet!) The gas that the Psychlos breathe is poison to humans and vice versa but at one point a suffocating Jonnie is able to escape from the dome the aliens have erected over most of Denver simply by diving into a pipeline that goes to the outside. And so forth. To their credit the scriptwriters managed to avoid some of the plot howlers in Hubbard's novel such as the atomic bomb that can vaporize a planet but not the other atomic bombs sitting next to it.Technically "Battlefield Earth" is a freaky mess. Evidently director Roger Christian thought it would be cool to film most of the movie at odd angles but it just ends up being disorienting. The human characters are at times difficult to tell apart since they are all long-haired and shaggy. The Psychlo atmosphere is purple so all the scenes inside the dome are dark and indigo-tinted. Unfortunately since the Psychlos are also long-haired and shaggy in the dark good guy and bad guy alike are identical silhouettes. Travolta appears to forget about Terl's pseudo-British accent about half the time. At the beginning of the movie the Psychlo weapons shoot gobs of green energy but at some point they start firing bullets instead. The sound effects are good and the computer-generated effects are OK - though better suited to "Babylon 5" than a big-budget movie - but the musical score is loud and overdramatic.But despite all of "Battlefield Earth's" faults and being forewarned by dozens of negative reviews in the press I actually had a hard time not enjoying it. It was just fun to watch. Certainly the novel it's based on is overlong poorly edited and in places just plain weird but it isn't the worst thing Hubbard ever wrote. I enjoyed the way the director switched between the Psychlo and human points of view - humans perceive Psychlos speaking gibberish while the Pscyhlos regard the humans as apes. It was evident that Travolta had fun hamming up his role as the Machiavellian and arrogant Terl. Unfortunately his lines consisting primarily of diabolical laughter and childish semantic games did get tiresome after a while. Multiple variations on the theme "I agreed we wouldn't spy on each other but I never agreed *I* wouldn't spy on *you*" can only go so far before getting silly. And the Psychlo technology is more or less the way I pictured it while reading the novel: grimy metallic and more functional than decorative.The idea of an influential Hollywood Scientologist producing a film based on a novel by the founder of Scientology has understandably raised some concerns that "Battlefield Earth" might be a subtle promotional tool for the controversial religion. But as reprehensible as Hubbard and Scientology are these fears are unfounded. A few of Hubbard's ideas come through - most notably that psychiatrists like the Psychlos regard humans as mere animals (Psychlo/psychiatrist - get it?). But nothing in the film is intrinsically Scientological. Face it - Hubbard was about as subtle as a bull in a china shop. Note for example the good guy/bad guy dichotomy in this film: the hero Jonnie Goodboy (get it?) Tyler can do no wrong while the evil Psychlos manipulate exploit blackmail drink a vile green intoxicant called kerbango and shoot the legs off cattle for kicks. If you want Scientology propaganda go read the 10-volume "Mission Earth" series a heavy-handed monstrosity replete with obvious Scientology references.Rather "Battlefield Earth" is a self-indulgent act of hero worship that John Travolta has finally put to film after nearly 20 years of trying. L. Ron Hubbard was an over-hyped self-promoting mediocre writer with an inflated sense of his own worth to society and in that respect "Battlefield Earth" is reflective of his character. But as an SF movie there have been worse films in the last couple of years. "Armageddon" and "Soldier" come to mind.

I really enjoyed the movie and now it's great to be able see all the behind the scenes fx and secrets of filming. My favorites include the camera angles and how the art director created the mood of the movie.

column4: This movie isn't so bad and I think it's quite actually good
column5: It isn't that bad and It is actually one of my favourite movie's and It would be good of them to make a sequel it was actually funny sometimes and the CG is good and I don't know why people think this movie is so bad. It is funny when Travolta is talking to Whitaker and he whip out the bartenders dead head and say our favourite bartender. It is a bit stupid when the humans learn to fly perfectly the jets and don't crash into a wall our nothing. Near the end of the movie when the dude has the nuclear bomb and explodes it on the Phsychlo home planet they blow up a couple of planets and kill like probably a 10 billion physchlos. Other than all this the movie was very good and should have made a trilogy.OR WILL THEY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!1

column4: The film was true to the book!
column5: It was very hard to go to see a movie that I had already read the book of but I found it very true to the original concept of the author. It would have been incredibly difficult to have gotten a book of that magnitude translated onto screen. I think John Travolta did a great job in his role and working to get the movie made in the first place. A great triumph!

I felt compelled to write my comments after seeing so many vehemently negative comments about this film. The movie had its departures from the book & it ran into trouble when it did that.It reminded me of an artistic European production in its coloration textures angles & general tone.The major weakness for me was that it moved so very fast I had a hard time keeping up with it so I saw it a second time with my family. I liked it better the 2nd time & saw minor bits of clever dialogue or nuances of character that whizzed by the first time. It was there but too fast to be easily accessible. I had read the book years ago & have also heard the Roddy McDowell audio book production. I consider the book a complete detailed universe of characters with a timeless message & story - simply great!So when I saw the movie it clicked with me. It was enjoyed by my family too. My grandson laughs at Terl's antics seeing him as a stupid villain who loses.If any person reads this wondering about Battlefield Earth I would only say read the book...if you like it then see the movie
Thought it was a sci fi spoof movie and it even failed at that. At least i dozed off for an hour and that's the only good thing about this disaster.

suspend disbelief.You know how many movies have reviews which state "suspend disbelief"?That is not possible with this film.It is that bad. One cannot suspend disbelief! 2 stars as a tribute to the actors and actresses who kept straight face and worked on this.

I have a feeling that this film will be appreciated more as time goes on. I also speculate that if a young person saw it without preconceptions that he or she would respond quite favorably.There is a simplicity and strength to the performances and the story that is surprisingly moving.John Travolta gives a brave perfomance sticking his neck out and doing a great job. Barry Pepper is terriific!This movie is classic sci fi in ideas and form.

Wow this could have been the sci-fi epic they're STILL claiming this to be cause the second half of this just turned into absolute garbage. I watched this for free on the plane and had to force myself to not switch it for something else.

If you were bored out of your mind and this was the only movie you can watching it regret but its not a enjoyable film by any means. The story is weird and not believable. It feels like a rip off of better more classic Science Fiction Novels and Films. If you are on the fence about watching this I would recommend you save your time

column4: Come on people  it's not that bad.
column5: When i first saw this film i was ten and immediately i fell in love with it. I believe it gave the message of the strength of the human spirit but when i watch it now well it's not as i remember. At first i had no background knowledge like Travolta was just bowing to the will and bizarre and pedophilic tendencies of good old LRH. I dono  i mean it is entertaining and still has elements of a time not so sceptical and more naive but essentially it's just great to watch when your drunk or stoned. If you get bored than think of Saturday Night Fever or Pulp Fiction.It always works for me.
Of the absolute worst movies I had ever seen. I am 74 years old & have been a movie goer since I was a child.

Please do not compare the movie with the 3 books of L. Ron Hubbard. We all know that books are always better. Battlefield Earth is one on the best Science Fiction movies I have seen in the last years. And I have seen many S.F. movies! John Travolta as Terl the Psychlo Chief of Security is very good in his job. Ok while watching the film you have the impression that everything goes a bit to fast. But that is the problem when you try to include every detail of the novel into the movie. At the end I want to make clear that 80% of all Science Fiction movies are bad!! So if there is a good S.F. movie coming out like Battlefield Earth do not vote so hard. I feel bad if you only give 25 points to such a good S.F. movie.
One of my favorite insomnia movies. A giant version of the Ferengi.

I read the book around 10 years ago in fact I read it several times the story is fabulous original I just love it. So I had to go and see it in theater. I was a bit afraid of the result but I've been amazed. The adaptation of the book is well done (despite the changes which are by the way logical and clever) the spirit of the book is there. What I particularly appreciated about this film is the way it's done I mean it's original images music and sounds are so powerful different. While watching it you are indeed in an other world. This film is different it's not a copy or is not inspired by an other film. It's more like a research of an new way of filming. Some kind of a preview of new science fiction. My conclusion is I love it. I know what I'm talking about I'm an ardent sci-fi fan. P.S. This comment is only a comment about a film I particularly appreciated nothing else.

L. Ron Hubbard would have advised against doing this movie because he had a realistic view of his writing skills. He was a gun for hire and paid by the word for any pulp genre. Scientologists should read Hubbard's prefaces to the very books they so venerate. Aside from being too long a book the pulp formula made the characterization shallow and cheesy. Aliens talked as if they stepped off the street of an American city so there was little hope of anything good coming out of it. Combine this with heavy backseat driving from Travolta and the church of Scientology and you have the Ideal film to show students what not to do. It was not an accident they chose Christian to direct. The book spent a lot of time justifying and explaining the improbable story a luxury you can't afford in film. It festered Right down to the ludicrous alien costumes with their huge over-sized boots that actually had made the Psychlos smaller and awkward. I believe Travolta and Kelly will need some extra sessions on the E meter to get back up on the Scientology food chain. They should take a tip from Mr. Hubbard who was never blinded by Faith and adoration. They might also read up on Heinlein one of his best buddies who wrote "Stranger in a Strange Land" the basis for Rael and company. Both men hated Psychology and loved a good joke. Great guys but they would have choked on their pop-corn had they seen this film

I have just watched this film but I did read the review here on IMDb before doing so.I must say I found the story line of the movie to be alright. There were many areas of the story that could of and should have been explained or covered better.The action in the film is simple and I don't feel it was under done in that respect.I enjoyed the actors and they did good job to help score the film better for me.I didn't expect much going into the movie given that it has taken out so many awards for being so BAD but I was surprised. The story needed more and the end was way too quick.Worth a once off look Overall i gave the film 3/10

Surprisingly true to the book (a real feat due to the book's size and sheer brilliance!) great special effects acting and cinematography. I laughed at the unexpected scenes (cameo by Kelly Preston "curbango" pun uttered by the Ker character and more). My favorite scene was the planet Psychlo -- they handled this far better than I thought possible. This was great sci-fi! I'm definitely getting the video and I can't wait to see the sequel and how the 'little gray man' is handled.

I enjoyed the movie. It was very fast paced and I had to watch it twice before I got a couple of important pieces of the plot - so pay attention!The special effects are amazing. Especially the part where ... (I won't spoil it for you) ... the audience was stunned after that one.If you read the book then don't expect the movie to be the same it is quite different but stands up on its own.BTW the book totally rocks.

column4: Objective Critic - Entertaining Book Awful Film [Perhaps]
column5: I maybe a little late in commenting this film however films like this come along very rarely and thus justify comment regardless. As an avid reader of science fiction and adventure stories during my youth I read Battlefield Earth and thoroughly enjoyed it. I would actually go as far as to say it was one of my favourite books at the time [perhaps my tastes were less refined]. Even then I was aware that L. Ron Hubbard was a rather unbalanced character as his Scientology church headquarters were less than 10 km from where I lived and thus the ravings of the church were general knowledge in my home county. I wondered then if the book would ever become a film hoping that it would. So when the film finally made it I was concerned by the reviews it was getting surely it couldn't be that bad. Now I have to be honest I have not seen the entire movie. Battlefield Earth is the only film that I found so bad that I was unwilling to endure its entirety. I have seen many bad films in my time but normally they begin to take on a comical character which allows their continued viewing. Battlefield Earth has no redeeming factors whatsoever. I would suggest that Battlefield Earth is more damaging to the church of scientology than the madness that they preach.

This movie is amazing from start-to-finish. Battlefield Earth is a fascinating work of art and everyone involved with this film should be nominated for the Academy Awards. Everything about it is just so compelling. If I could give Battlefield Earth a higher rating I wouldn't let it pass by like a cold day in Hell. Scientology rules!

column4: I won't be converting to Scientology anytime soon.
column5: You know if the Matrix never came around I never would have seen this movie. However that (expletive) movie made me think that sci-fi movies were on their way back. Then I saw Pitch Black the second worst movie I ever saw in a theater (1st place will always be "Daylight" starring Sylvester Stallone). And now I have seen Battlefield Earth. It might be a long time before I watch a sci-fi movie again. I just have a hard time believing as many others have that a superior race could find strains of gold in the Rocky Mountains but not find Fort Knox. I find it hard to believe that cave and forest dwellers who thought that statues were frozen people could learn how to pilot a Harrier in a week. Now it occurred to me that perhaps they learned it that quickly because after all it is a thousand years from now and surely the brain has evolved but I mean they think STATUES are frickin' PEOPLE. There is a lot to swallow in this movie as in all sci-fi movies but this was a just too much. Now the overall plot isn't that bad I suppose. From what people tell me some of it doesn't make sense because parts from the book were deleted. HOW BIG IS THIS BOOK? It's slated to be a trilogy and you can't have the movies make sense? Anyways I can accept that Johnny Goodboy whatever could learn stuff that fast (after all I accepted that Neo could learn that fast in Matrix didn't I?) but how does he teach hundreds if not thousands of people just as fast? And why in the year 2000 do we have a bomb that one person could carry (Is this the "suitcase bomb" from "Wag the Dog"?) that blows up (and I mean BLOWS UP) a planet which is supposed to be much much bigger than ours? And how many people and Psychlos are we dealing with here? That never seems clear to me and most of the final battle scene just completely escaped me unless there was a main character in it. Speaking of characters what was Travolta doing here? I wasn't able to tell if we were supposed to laugh at him or be afraid of him. That stupid laugh was funnier and less purposeful than Dr. Evil's I mean throw me a frickin' bone here. Other than that I didn't think the acting was too bad.For some reason though I was able to watch this movie without getting too upset. Perhaps it's because Pitch Black had already lowered my expectations of Sci-Fi movies but when I was watching the movie I turned my brain off and only since I've had time to digest it have I gotten so mad. Unlike everyone else the tilted screen really didn't bother me that much it wasn't like it was Blair Witch or anything. So that is why this does not get into the "Pitch Black"/"Daylight" levels and I give this a 4 out of 10 and I would attribute that to the special effects.

column4: Better with age and by comparison
column5: If you have exhausted your never seen Sci Fi films and haven't considered BFE then this is worth your time. Since its release there have been a slew of really bad Sci-fi especially if you have sat through the Sci-Fi channel releases and made for DVD. This had a budget and it shows. It amounts to a bad Hollywood Movie but it at least qualifies as a legitimate film. Yes bad but much better then most of the terribly bad Sci-Fi. And spiritual what? Its just a save earth from the aliens movie... If ID4 didn't come out first or at all... This movie would have had a life of its own and still might build a cult following over time...

column4: Not the worst film I've ever seen but...
column5: I really wanted to love this film. I'd heard all the negative reviews and I'd hoped that it was all down to prejudice against L. Ron Hubbard. I'd seen the trailers and it looked good. The clips I'd seen looked good. But the film as a whole just doesn't work. I won't even try to list all the things that are wrong with this film because there's a 1000 word limit on this. I think that the thing that really sunk it was the lack of humour if there had been a few good one-liners it would've lifted the whole thing. When you think of a great film you always think about certain scenes. Sexy scenes funny scenes or gobsmacking action scenes. But this film has none of the above. Some of the action scenes might have been impressive if they hadn't been ruined by the overuse of slow motion. All in all the film was ruined by the script's reliance on contrived situations. It was too easy for the heroes to save the day. If only someone with a decent grasp of the English language had given the script a quick once over then maybe we might have been spared this monstrosity. But on the plus side John Travolta gave a good performance as Terl considering the useless stupid character he was given to play. If only Terl had been as clever as he thought he was then the film might have worked. Might have. And Kelly Preston was a very sexy Psychlo. Still having said all of this I'm planning to see it again. It might improve with repeat viewing. It's not the worst film ever made but it is a letdown. Warner Bros. must be getting sick of always the studio that delivers the turkeys.

column4: So many scientific holes for science based religion flick
column5: OK. Aliens come in and dominate the human population. OK I can buy it. Some humans escape and basically become caveman and woman again. OK far fetched but giving the whole conquering of us maybe I can buy it. Here's were it gets really bad. There is a line in the movie where Travolta boasts about how it took only but 9 minutes to conquer the Earth". Keep this line in mind as you read the rest of this. The alien beings are powerful and seem to know a lot about the Earth history and historical figures. Yet they couldn't figure out that the primary mineral they are there to collect (gold) has its largest concentration in Fort Knox. They were so intelligent they could pick up any version of an encyclopedia to look up the word gold and have a greater understanding of where the earth's already mined supply's are. Then Jet fuel has an expiration date of about 50 years. Yet many many years later it still holds the chemical balance to work in these aircraft that the caveman humans learn to fly in 2 weeks. Oh wait I hear it again "9 Minutes to conquer the Earth". Then caveman take a crash course on how to fly a jet and use the gold from fort knox to buy the time. From caveman to fighter jet pilot is a huge leap of evolution my friend. My grandfather was a pilot and this movie is a pure comedy to him. Oh OK say we are complete morons and buy all the crap that has been spooned fed to us at this point. Now an alien nation that was so far advanced that (yes the 9 minute thing)conquered us. And you figure their advancements from that point would have increased even to higher levels. yet they end up getting their butts kicked by caveman pilots in obsolete jets with expired fuel to end the movie. So basically the technology that got its but kicked almost 1000 years ago is now the ultimate weapons again. Its like us getting into a huge war with Iceland and Iceland breaks out the catapult and destroys us. Nice work Travolta and L Ron Hubbard. If you have a religion with science in the name you might want to do some scientific research on your own film before you release it to the public. Can you say F-. Nope I can't the humor in its flaws alone bump it up to an F.

I doubt it possible for a frequent movie viewer to be without any preconceptions of this movie. It has to be one of the most talked about "Bombs" in the history of cinema. Even so you can enjoy it.....no really! Read on.....Fool yourself. Pretend that this is a gloriously deliberately tongue-in-cheek farce of a movie ( Think the later Nightmare On Elm Street pictures ) and you may actually come out the other side with a grin on your face. Try and take it seriously and judge it by any cinematic scale other than the Stupidfunnypieceofcrapometer and disappointment will leave a bitter taste on your tongue as it fails to come close to describing the feelings that viewing this lemon seem to inspire in everybody but the most rabid Scientologists.John. For shame.

column4: I really enjoyed this first installment of the terrific book.
column5: The movie based on the epic book picks up the flavour of Buck Rogers in terms of the overall "colour" of that era and movies from that time. The story was engrossing and kept me wanting to know more. I even saw it a second time and found it even better the second viewing.

Battle Field Earth is one of those movies that in the long run will become a classic Sci Fi movie and seen as very innovative. The sets the camera angles the CG work are all way more than you ever see in most movies.

The only thing good about this movie is the camera its really high quality and makes the film look like an actual blockbuster and also i like the name but other than that nothing is good about this movie from character design story script setting special effects and even the poster i've seen really horrible movies but those are almost all independent or made to be bad this was distributed by Warner Bros! You would think they would check for quality! I though Marvel films were bad or Godzilla 98 I thought that was as bad as big studio films get mockbusters uwe boll films and nostalgia critic skits are better than this film! This isn't the worst film i've seen Empire takes that place nor is the director the worst Neil Breen takes that placebut those are both independent this is the worst big studio film i've ever seen but not bottom 10 but bottom 100 i hate this film.

This film must surely become a cult classic. John T playing his usual cool self strange special effects and those great boots. I had read many reviews saying this film was dire but hadn't enjoyed a film so much for ages. A lot seems to have been crammed into the last 20 minutes or so as if they started to run out of time but overall I really enjoyed it.

No bones about it Battlefield Earth is a bad film. And you know it right away -- from the moment Pepper throws himself on the ground and yells "NO!!!!" And it pretty much stays bad from start to finish. The story the camera work (what was with that wacky angle in every shot?) the acting -- it would be impossible to list everything wrong with it.But to be perfectly honest and I'm amazed to say it Battlefield Earth was not a boring bad film. And as for Travolta's over-the-top approach? With an outfit like that on and lines like that what else was he gonna do? At least he seemed to have a little fun with it -- and ultimately I guess I did too. A little. Very little.

The major flaw is that you can't make a 2 hour movie out of a 1000+ pages book. It happened to Troy as well! Remember? I would admit that the acting could have been much better given the actors involved at least given their names...Also the movie manages to make the aliens so stupid I would hardly imagine they only needed 9 minutes to conquer earth. The 1000 years old planes m16 nukes and so on are another Big blunder of the movie. Not to mention the flight simulator as someone already said was powering form WHERE? There are indeed too many errors in this movie too much money down the drain. I cannot understand how you can direct a movie and not stop and think that it would be impossible for a caveman to fly a supersonic in just one week. At least give me a DAMN good reason to believe that!Anyone smart enough to conquer earth in 9 minutes would stop and think how could the humans melt the gold in bars without the technology to do so? It's like a cow who comes and gives you the milk already bottled and you shout at it about the time it had to do the job :)Simply awful yet the movie had some potential. And it is not underrated it is simply a bad movie. Even if the book were great the movie should have been MUCH better!

column4: Sci-Fi fans read this. Some people gave this high reviews on IMDb? I will explain.
column5: Now I'm not a person who likes all sorts of bad movies. For instance I think that "Dragonball: Evolution" and the American version of "Death Note" were disasters. I don't just like all movies so hear my thoughts on this one.There are a bunch of high reviews here for this movie. A small percentage of people actually like this movie and I happen to be on of them. If you have the correct expectations and you're a hardcore Sci- Fi fan then you may sincerely be one of the people can enjoy this.WHAT TO EXPECT: This is a low-budget post-apocalyptic Sci-Fi with over the top script and acting. It's done more in an old-school style instead of going for realism like movies nowadays (for instance Nolan's Batman trilogy which tries to be realistic).As a huge Sci-Fi fan I liked the movie because it has what I wanted form it: Futuristic visuals and a post-apocalyptic story.Visually I enjoyed the alien spaceship designs and certain environments (such as the alien colonial base and city ruins) even if they were low- budget.The post-apocalyptic story is interesting it follows one the most known Sci-Fi novels. Personally I haven't read the novel so can't comment on that much.The first 5 minutes leaves the worst impression (acting and script wise) but it got interesting after the aliens come in.BOTTOM LINE. HERE IS THE KEY POINT:I wasn't bothered by the acting or the script BECAUSE... Being a Sci- Fi fan the post-apocalyptic story and futuristic visuals made this into an enjoyable experience even if the script and acting isn't what you would call Oscar worthy. That's why some people really like this movie.Most people are extremely disappointed with the acting dialogues and cheap visuals. So much that it's considered the worst movie ever. Based on my review if you think you can enjoy it for what it is give it a chance.

The original premise is kind of cool I guess. Seems realistic that humans would go all religious about the invaders and it's a nice touch that the scavenger humans assume the massive statues are ancient humans who were turned into stone.I mostly just wanted to point out a major gaping plot hole I've not seen mentioned much - why do the aliens seem to think humans are a primitive species incapable of anything beyond the most basic manual labour so much so they find it completely inconceivable that one could fire a gun when THERE ARE CITIES FULL OF SKYSCRAPERS EVERYWHERE? John Travolta even mentions a military confrontation when the invaders arrived.Not to mention they don't seem to think it's weird that "man animals" have exactly the same anatomy as themselves the only real difference being height and eye colour.

column4: So bad it is barely/painfully funny

This movie took the Raspberry Awards by a storm in 2000 (I think it won 7 awards including worst director worst film and worst actor) which speaks volumes about how good it is.When I watched it I did not know about Scientology so any criticisms I had at the time had nothing to do with its Scientology connections.SPOILER WARNINGSIn the year 2000 Earth was conquered (in 9 minutes) by an evil race known as Psyclos who bare an uncanny resemblance to Klingons. Fast forward 1000 years later and Mankind is an endangered species who only survive by hiding in radiated areas where the Psyclos don't go due to a violent reaction between their breath-gas and radiation. One Human (Pepper) doesn't believe in the stories about monsters and leave home in search of a better life. He is captured by a Psyclo and then placed in the hands of Travolta. Travolta detests Earth and sees gold as his ticket back to Psyclo. He puts Pepper onto a machine which teaches him the Psyclo language mining techniques and strangely enough how to use Psyclo weapons and teaches them about the Psyclo weaknesses. However Pepper uses his new found knowledge to start a revolt. He arms his fellow humans with ancient human weapons and all is set for the final showdown between Humanity and Psyclo.To be blunt the film was utter rubbish. There were numerous plot holes (Humanity's technology failed badly in 2000 but is more than a match for Psyclo in 3000 and the cavemen manage to learn to fly and use guns in a week and despite conquering billions of galaxies the Psyclos are really stupid and cannot shoot for fudge). The dialogue is atrocious (the script writer must have been paid for the amountof times the words ''leverage'' and ''man animal'' and ''rat brain'' were used. The Special Effects were good and the acting was okay and really are the only things that save this film from 0/10. Ridiculous plot holes and a ridiculous plot holes and ridiculous dialogue ruin this filmutterly.

column4: The best movie I have ever seen.
column5: This movie was a phenomenon. My friend Michael and I were hit like a broken arrow by the quality of this movie. We were expecting to grease it up with insults as our friend Martin had done but after watching the triumphant blow out in the mad city at the end we could not help but shout "Look who's talking!"Basically the chemistry between Whitaker and Travolta escalates from sizzling to electric by this powerhouse duo. The two actors have no trouble in showing their characters' primary colors. Travolta pulls off Terl's arrogant swagger and slippery persona without a hitch; Whitaker convincingly reveals his thin red line of compassion towards the man-animals. The face/off between the experts is perfect!Barry Pepper is sure to reflect on this movie as the high point of his career. Like an urban cowboy his character Ker rode unafraid into the ancient wilderness. Kept alive only by a dead mouse here and there he lives moment by moment always thinking of the limpid eyes of an angel his lovely wife Carlo (Kim Coates she's so lovely) he rebels against the white man's burden the Psychlo! Certainly not a civil action.The psychlo are obsessed with mining chains of gold from the Earth. Gold the rarest element in the universe is traded as vociferously among the Psychlo as it is among mankind today so it would be an understatement to say that the Psychlo could care less about collateral damage in their mining operations. Talk about a domestic disturbance!The ending is fantastic! I was as happy as the humans were to see the horrible poisonous enclosures destroyed. No longer would the humans be boys in the plastic bubble; they were free free from the devil rain.WATCH THIS MOVIE! MAKE LIKE A SWORDFISH AND GET TO YOUR VIDEO STORE NOW!

column4: Fun Grade B Sci Fi with John Travolta !
column5: Personally my hubby and I found this movie very entertaining when viewed as a grade B Sci Fi. If your a true lover of Sci Fi including grade B and can appreciate movies that are just fun Sci Fi with little meat to them you won't be disappointed with this one. Plus if you are a Travolta fan you will enjoy seeing him play the part of a Alien as a most entertaining new way to see him in a new light and so different from his other movies but a lot of fun! Hubby and I have always hoped that John Travolta would do another Sci Fi movie again after seeing how well he did his cruel alien character in this one. I am more then surprised it was rated so low. Travolta makes a great alien in his Klingon like get up and plays it to the hilt with grade B "gusto". In fact we thought his Klingon like costume was very acceptable. Consider how many Sci Fi movies mimic the Alien monster movies with Sigourney Weaver etc. Why should Travolta not take a good idea and make it his own. He is a terrific and scary alien in this movie. We were engaged through out the entire movie with his ruthless and heartless character which he did a fine job portraying. It was interesting to see mankind as a "lesser species" forced to be slaves to a alien race. The masterly and entirely arrogant alien Travolta plays is most believable and menacing. He struts around like a bull in a bull fight threatening any second to erupt and destroy anything any idea and anyone in his way! You keep thinking where is his weakness? You will never see the surprising ending of this movie coming! But you will be so pleased at the sudden twist of fate it affords! Can't say more or would give it away. Watch this movie if you love fun grade B Sci Fi and enjoy John Travolta movies in general. Travolta is a blast in this underrated movie.

That's OK because the plot was disconnected anyway.I'm an admirer of Hubbard's work and found Battlefield Earth a wonderful book. When a book is adapted to the movie screen I let the movie speak for itself instead of making expectations of my reading. In this way the movie is more enjoyable. However the screenwriters should have gone back and read and re-read the book. Maybe they would have gotten a clue about constructing a plot.Robert the Fox is a main character in the book but you wouldn't know it by the movie. The two met in Scotland after Jonny escaped from Terl. You'd never know it by the movie. There are a couple of major Psychlo and human players missing which accounts for the holes in the plot.Don't waste your money seeing this loser. Go rent Attack of the Killer Tomatoes instead.

column4: Horrible Film from a great book
column5: This film was absolutely terrible. I believe that is pretty much the consensus. However I would simply like to add that although the film was horrendous the book was excellent. I am not much a sci-fi type but the book really was a great work in my opinion. Then they tried to take a 1000+ page novel and turn it into a movie? Why? How does one turn a complex 1000+ page work of art into a 130 page movie script? Well I guess this film showed it cannot be done properly. After being a fan of the book and recommending the story (film included before I saw it) to so many people I feel like I owe the world an apology. If you are at all curious about the story and how the holes could be filled in check out the book. I gave the movie a 2 instead of a 1 because of my devotion to the book which I feel is worthy of a 9 or 10.

column4: L Ron Hubbard meets Hollywood.Big Screenplay
column5: I'm sure it was an entertaining read as a book. And follower John Travolta fell obligated to see his master memorialized on the "big screen ". I have not even read any of the reviews for this movie on this website. But I will bet my next 10 paychecks and yours that there are parallel observations.Ok. Nothing fit. The acting and directing... Left a lot to be desired. A lot of assumptions were made that the viewers would already know or had a knowledge foundation to draw from when understanding details. The music score it really didn't fit some of the scenes. Details were murky. And in a post apocalyptic movie... Does everyone need to be wearing canvas colored clothing and sport long disheveled hairdos?The plot was simplistic. Honestly this seemed like Cliff Notes to other movies were the captive becomes the savior. This movie was at best a mix between Mad Max meets The Postman.As a researcher I drew more from learning about the author of the book that this movie was based on. Now... That is a real story!

I ask only that for those of you who have watched the movie give the book a chance. For those of you lucky enough not to have watched the movie....don't. Just go ahead and read the book. I read the book first and loved it. When I saw there was a movie out I was ecstatic. Upon watching the movie I wished that someone had beaten the idea out of me. Regardless despite the ....suckiness? of the movie the book it was originated from was excellent. Movie : 1 out of 10 Book : 9 out of 10

I give it an 8 out of 10. It's not incredible but rather a solid film with a great story and lots of eye candy.

column4: Not horrible bad with a lot of plot holes but not the worst movie ever made
column5: I didn't think it was the worst movie ever made. First and foremost there was a lot of unintentional comedy. True the fact that all of the jets and the declaration of independence and even cities survived over 1000 years is kind of hard to believe but who cares? It was entertaining. It had the basic action movie script good guy versus evil guy helpless situation good guy somehow manages to defeat all-powerful bad guy. I was rooting for Barry Pepper and the humans to beat up those aliens. column4: Nowhere near as bad as others say here
column5: 1. It's not any worse than any average sci-fi film out there. 2. All sci-fi films require suspension of disbelief - and this requires nothing more than anything out of any of the star trek star wars Matrix or SG1 universes. Even someone with advanced degrees in astrophysics and cosmology can enjoy sci-fi movies - and the gaping holes in known science or logic in this movie are no greater than any other sci-fi movie or show - you could take apart any movie - even Casablanca - with it's flaws - but that would only ruin the movie. 3. I don't know or care about the author or his religion and followers - it's irrelevant to the movie. Christian Muslim Mormon - they've all got ridiculous myths beliefs and followers - followers who have to suspend logic in real life everyday - so why not for a movie? 4. I have to assume that people must have come into this predisposed to dislike it. I saw it on TV years ago just channel surfing - partway through - and found it completely distracting and enjoyable. Perhaps it's the Lord of the Flies crowd mentality but just drop the attitude bias or thought that it's real and IF you really like sci-fi you might find this movie quite enjoyable. 5. It's got more-advanced and bigger-than-human sinister aliens (Independence Day) a devastated future earth (planet of the apes) a protagonist standing up for the human race (Stargate) A hero and a woman standing up together against 'the man' (Total Recall) wily & plucky humans (Flash Gordon Buck Rogers) a few explosions and harrier jets (Arnold S. movies) etc. - what's not to like? I'm giving this an 8 partly because I like it and partly because it doesn't deserve the collective ~2.0 it has now. There are tons of actual 2.0 deserving movies with 7.0 rating on the IMDb simply because of crowd mentality - ever notice that most new movies hit the street with at least a 7.0 but most drop down to at least a 5.0 once they're no-longer current - especially younger-audience movies?

column4: This is science FICTION everyone should realize this and get over it...
column5: I love this movie I have watched it several times and it hurts me to see it get lambasted by almost everyone. Sure there are holes in the plot physics not behaving as they should etc but this is science FICTION not reality based drama. The book is fantastic and answers a lot of the questions asked by the people prepared to blast this movie. The humans use the aliens technology to learn how to fly etc. Who knows what technology will be like in 1000 years from another planet?!? The Psyclos arrogance to everything non Psyclo is a parallel to America's arrogance to the rest of the world as it is today. After millenniums of being the master race of the universe they have stagnated and look down upon all other species/races with contempt. Their society is based on corruption and I can't help but think LRH intended this to parallel the consumer capitalism that rules the western world today. Read the book I am not a scientologist nor a Christian and I think most of the disliking of this movie is due to prejudice (towards Scientology)and people not following the story and filling in the blanks themselves. This is no worse an attempt at the scifi genre as any other movie including the completely unoriginal Star Wars trilogy Star Trek etc. I can't wait until someone gets the balls to do a movie of LRH's Mission Earth decology what a great yarn that one is full of corruption temptation greed lust and science FICTION at its best. I gave this 8 out of 10 it could have been longer and more in depth by explaining all the little bits people with no imagination couldn't figure out for themselves but overall it is a good attempt at a very complex and long piece of science FICTION.
