column4: All in all a good movie.
column5: I don't understand why people rubbish this movie I found it to be very entertaining. I think people forget that movies are for entertainment only and not always a reflection of the world around us therefore they don't always have to be believable. I think people are watching far to much reality TV. This movie is set 1000 years into the future and therefore should not in any way be compared with life as we know it. I found this movie to be both funny and entertaining and I thought John Travolta Barry Pepper & Forest Whitaker all did very well in their individual roles. This is not a movie to be taken seriously and if it is taken seriously then maybe people need to get out more. I guess I can only say that if you didn't like this movie then maybe SciFi isn't for you.Battlefield Earth is set 1000 years in the future in the year 3000. the Earth has been taken over by an Alien Race and People are treated like we would treat monkeys. Jonnie (Barry Pepper) sets out from his tribe to find a better life and to verify the existence of the demons (Aliens). He meets up with two men out hunting for food and they bond and become good friends after an auspicious beginning. When Jonnie and his two new friends are captured by the Aliens they are taken to a processing plant there they are imprisoned and made into slaves Jonnie is taken by Terl (John Travolta) who then attempts to educate him with a learning machine in the ways of his race in an attempt to get them to mine gold for his own personal gain Jonnie realising that this education is the key to there freedom and uses the learning machine as much as he can and with his new found knowledge relays the rest or the captives to rebel against their captors.
If you liked this film here are other titles I suggest for you:Mamma MiaThunder Force(it's not out yet but I am predicting this review will be read in the future): Thunder Force 2.

There was so much good material to work from yet they still managed to create a movie that won an astonishing seven razzies. It's quite a remarkable achievement if you think about it but certainly not in a good way. As an avid science fiction reader I prefer to read a book before I see the movie but in this case I don't think that was such a good idea. Yes this was a bad movie but amazingly enough it's even worse if you know what the story was meant to be like. L. Ron Hubbard wrote a true masterpiece and it is really disappointing to think of how it was misrepresented in the movie that bears the same name of Battlefield Earth.The original book is really just too big to try and cram into a two-hour movie; I think that the 1050 pages and 400000 words would be a good indication of that. Just look at what happened to Dune: they took one of the most monumental works in science fiction and turned it into a movie that was nearly impossible to follow. I'll have to see it again to see if it makes more sense after reading the book but still it's just the thought of taking a masterpiece and mutilating it beyond recognition.In Battlefield Earth the story was chopped up so badly that the majority of the characters in the book weren't even mentioned in the movie. Example: (Caution: Contains spoilers [not that it matters])* Robert the Fox- The Scottish war chief who is more or less Jonnie's main helper.* Dunneldee Stormalong and Glencannon- Other Scotsmen who help with taking back the planet.* The seventy-seven remaining Scots- Where were they? Did you see any Scottish people? I didn't see any Scottish people.* The Chinese- I didn't see any of them either.* The thirty-odd alien races- Nope. Definitely no aliens besides the Psychols.Where did they all go? You might be asking if you actually care and I would be concerned if you did. Well I have one word for you: Carlo. Yes Carlo. The guy with the dark curly hair who tried the suicide dive into the dome that failed at first. I'm not sure exactly how they managed to get eighty-one people into one character but somehow they did if rather unsuccessfully. Actually there was a Robert the Fox in the movie but I didn't realize this until reading the cast list. Not to mention that only about a third of the book was covered in the movie but I can't imagine what it would have been like had they tried to put all 1050 pages into two hours. Well . . . no it's definitely too frightening to think about it. They would have been better off just not attempting to make the movie in the first place. The writer didn't even follow the plot. For those of you who haven't read the book it might be interesting for you to know that when Jonnie was captured along by Terl (the movie really screwed this up) he was kept for nearly a year until they both went to Scotland and picked up the eight-one people from there. I guess they just wanted to condense the story so they captured Jonnie with a few other people and took him to a compound where there were already a few hundred humans. The real stinger to this all is this quote from the official Battlefield Earth website and this is a real quote:". . .the grand adventure of Battlefield Earth awaited only the right script adaptation before everything came together to make it a movie reality. With a Corey Mandell screenplay which captures the immense scope and irrepressible spirit of Hubbard's novel that time has at last arrived."Poor Corey Mandell; you almost feel sorry for him. Almost.

column4: It's a Science Fiction not a historical fact movie and I really liked it!
column5: I grew up reading Sci-Fi and still do. Some classic science movies are made to make us think while some like this one are made for entertainment. If you relax and enjoy the special effects you would like the movie too. If you begin to question how you think things should look after time or apply scientific reasoning to everything you will hate it - like most did. Leave the "Oh! That couldn't happen" thoughts out lighten up sit back and enjoy a good action movie like I did. I watch it every few months and still don't see why so many people trashed it I really like it.

Like the title suggests that pretty much sums up my thoughts for this film. Just... what?If I had to be completely 100% honest I would say this: This film makes absolutely zero goddamn sense. First off why is almost every single scene transition the same exact goofy window swipe? It's like watching a PowerPoint presentation put together by a kid in high school thing is their presentation would probably make more sense than this sh!tshow.Secondly this film is so bad that it lacks the ability to have subtitles on the one streaming service I could find it on (Stan). However I am kinda glad because even without the subtitles the dialogue still sounds wack. I'd rather try and decipher a 1000-year-old ancient Egyptian scroll from beneath the Earth than understand what's being said in the movie.I suck at writing reviews so I'm just going to end it here. I could rave on for HOURS because there is so much to say about this monstrosity but I want to save my breath and avoid getting arthritis from typing any more. So yeah do not watch this. You have been warned.

When I first watched this movie in the cinema and the year 2000 I left thinking it was absolute trash. Focusing on all the holes in the technology the accents and the rushed initial storyline. Watching it again 20 years later with lower expectations I actually found it highly enjoyable. I liked the aesthetic and the old school special effects. I actually found John Travolta's performance to be surprisingly refreshing after putting aside my initial criticism of these sky Demons having American accents. If you are a sci-fi fan you've got some time and you've watched everything else on Netflix. It's worth another go. I have a new appreciation for the movie.

column4: Utter utter dribble. I could pull a better movie out of my...head.
column5: Well I read the book and thought it was fine. I watched the movie and I to this day cannot think of a word to describe how badly the screenwriters mangled the story. I watched this movie about two years ago or so and the faults are burned into my brain to this very day. There are so many I will only focus on the worst I can think of.Firstly Johnny is the first human the Psychlos find in years! They don't have large cages full of them...EVER! The most humans in a cage at one time are two: Johnnie's love interest and her sister.Second the "learning machine" for lack of a better name was brought to Johnny by Terl not the other way around. I wonder how many hundreds of psychlos would it take to carry that room-sized monstrosity they used in the movie.Third the method of destruction of Psychlo is so corrupted from the novel that it literally gave me a headache when I saw it. That one warhead would do bupkis to Psychlo. Anyone who read the book would know that THERE IS A SHIELD on the Psychlo platform. It took about 8 LARGE nukes to destroy Psychlo and even then they still neither broke through the shield NOR ignited the atmosphere. They shattered the heavily mined-out crust causing the planet to collapse on itself.Next I am disgusted that the Psychlos themselves were done as having anything in common with humans besides two arms two legs and a head. They had claws not long nails. Glowing orb-like eyes not regular ones. Johnnie's face was about level with Terl's belt. Then there was the breath masks. Before Terl took Johnnie into the dome Johnny had never seen his face therefore the breath mask covers their ENTIRE face not two small hoses into the nose.Another thing Terl reveled in molesting tormenting and hurting humans. The runt mechanic (I forget his name and can't find my book) liked Johnny and his work crew and would not shoot one of them whereas Terl would have no qualms about killing ALL of them but for the large quantities of gold in the irradiated mountains hence inaccessible to him.Sixth what happened to the other 18 or so minesites across the world? (No seriously I can't remember precisely but I think they somehow disappeared in the movie. Yes 18 or so ENTIRE minesites complete with dome. I also did not notice the gas drone either. Or any of the other races in the novel.) What I DID notice was that there was a rather large buildup of Psychlo forces on Psychlo. If they are a mining company why would they have such massed forces when they have not been alerted to any aggressive activities? I'll leave that one to the director.And I won't even begin to describe why it was a despicable decision to disclude the (second half? more like last three quarters.) of the book in the movie as it is so integrated into the first sections that it would leave plot holes big enough for trucks to fall through with no difficulties.Now you might say that I can't complain that the movie is THAT horrendously...bad...but I've read the book so yes I can and I do.This movie compared to what it could have been is pure rancid dribble. On a scale of 1 to 10 I'd give it a -5 but the scale doesn't go that low. I am VERY disappointed in you Mr. Christian.P.S. If I have made any errors it's because I am writing this purely from 2 year plus memory with no material to correlate my statements against. Yet I reckon I could still make a better movie of this book than they did.
